This is a housing for sonoff touch devices. It is designed in a way, that you only drill holes in the wall where the original light switches cover them when ever you want to uninstall it again. Because of this, the holes are in a bad position for screwing and you might need to drill them at an angle. Of course a different solution would be better here, for example with a snap in that you screw in earlier, but it was quickly designed and feel free to remix it to solve this issue.
The socket of the Company "Jung" fits exactly into this design, compared to the video, these sockets are available in clear white aswell.

edit: I just added 2 covers to use, if you want to insert Jung switches as trigger for a standard Sonoff instead of sonoff touch. Pictures to that will be updated later.

Have fun!

title: Prototype Add-ons for Brandon2255p's Slim Wallet Remix

description.text:
These are a few prototype add-on pieces for Brandon2255p's Slim Wallet 4.0. I added a clasp to hold the wallet firmly closed, and a small strip to constrain the card on the outside of the wallet so it is not prone to sliding out easily.

The clasp is very satisfying to use and easy to operate with your thumb. Before the clasp, I was able to shake the wallet and my cards would fall out. Now it's securely closed and the case will not open accidentally.

I attached these parts to Brandon's prototype version of the wallet (using a tiny amount of superglue on PLA) and it works splendidly.

STL file for the extra parts is attached, along with photos showing their placement, and a short video showing how they work.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GNUUSow4GZ8

These should be printed at 100% infill.

Thanks Brandon for your remixes and I look forward to future versions of your wallet!

description.text:
This is the Valus A6 210 Racing Drone.

My intention with the Valus A6 was to create a drone racing frame that was small, light weight, but still stiff enough to survive a crash without breaking in to pieces, but above all was printable on a standard 220x220 print bed. After multiple itteration, lessons learned from trying and information gathered from UAVFutures channel (big fan of the Channel) here is the Valus A6 Drone Racing Frame.

The frame consists out of 6 parts:

  • Frame
  • Cross brace M3
  • side frame (x2)
  • camera mount
  • reinforcement plate (VTX mount)

Suggested setup:

  • Motors ==> Racerstar BR2205 2300 KV
  • ESC ==> Racerstar RS30A lite
  • FC ==> SP Racing F3
  • PDB ==> Matek FCHUB-6S
  • VTX ==> Eachine TX801
  • Camera ==> Eachne TVL1000
  • Props ==> Dal Cyclone 5045C

Other parts:

  • M3 hex nut (x2)
  • M3x10mm (x8)
  • 5mm stand-offs (x8) (for PDB and FC mount)
  • Plastic M3 screws 10mm (x4) (for PDB and FC mount)
  • Battery strap 10mm (x1)

80%

All parts can be printed without support except for the reinforcement plate.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with hole for pulley mounting up.   No support needed, just a little cleaning out of the nut slot.

title: Uconduit - Move Z-axis motors and redesign Y-axis pulley mount

description.text:
Was having problems with the Z-axis thread rod couplings coming a little loose, then the threaded rod for that axis would drop out of the coupling. Most of the time it was due to the coupling cracking a little between the motor shaft and threaded rod. Tried a few times to reprint the couplings. After a while I thought a metal coupling would be stronger than the plastic, but that would not completely guaranty the threaded rod would not come off. I figured if the rod continues to fall down, maybe the motor would be better suited on the bottom of the printer. By moving the motor to the bottom, with a little help from gravity the rod should never fall up.

Printed two more sets of corner motor mounts so I could mount them at the bottom without having to take the entire frame apart. Just left the old motor mounts in place at the top, and add two more motor mounts at the bottom of the printer (see new white motor mounts). Purchased two metal couplings, flipped the motor/threaded rod assembles to bottom of the printer, inverted the Z axis motor direction in the Marlin software.

That should have solved all my problems, but during the removal of the top mounted motors, I noticed the Y-rod mounting that held the belt pulley was bent off to the side (see picture of old one). Most likely warped the plastic by being over aggressive on the belt tension. Decided to redesign those pulley mounts by making them stiffer somehow. The Y axis rod holder was right up next to where the original Z-motors were mounted. Used the old unused motor mounts to anchor the end of the Y-axis pulley. Now the pulley is bolted to a block which mounts to the conduit frame and is held in place by bolting it to the old motor mounts in the corner (see new red parts in picture).

Will publish more pictures when It is completely back together and printing

Migbot i3

title: Lower trigorilla mount for delta printer

description.text:
The Trigorilla board that comes with Anycubic linear plus seems a bit too close to the hotbed so I designed a lower mount that also should allow for a better cable management.

The holes on the margins are for zip-ties (2-3 mm width) that will hold the cables in position.

It can be printed at almost any resolution as long as the piece will not fall apart under pressure.
I used 0.4 mm layer height with 20% infill but I would recommend a lower layer height.

This should work with any printer that uses a 2020 extrusion as frame as long as it fits inside.

The shorter version (the one in the pictures) will work fine if you do not need the usb cable. Otherwise you will need to cut a bit of the plastic from the cable stress relief.

The longer version adds 2 cm extra space to allow the usb cable to fit without force.

title: FIX for Mobile Phone Universal Magnetic Car Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I already had a ProClip Angled Dash Mount installed in my car from a few phones ago. Instead of buying another one-off mount for my current phone I decided to try a Universal Magnetic Car Mount and stuck it to the ProClip base with the included double sided foam tape. Well the tape didn't last a month in the hot weather here in the Southeastern US (and it was October). So to fix it I got out the digital calipers designed something in Tinkercad and printed it on my new 3D printer. What I came up with is a custom base for the steel ball of the magnetic mount to snap fit into with holes to mount the whole thing to the ProClip base on my dash. This thing is working great so far. I'm hopeful that the solid printed PETG will stand up to the heat this summer. Fingers X'd.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this model originally at only 15% infill.  There were spots in the bottom of the cup area where there were unwanted holes.  Because of this I coated the inside of the cup with food safe silicone.  I would recommend a higher infill, possibly even as high as 50% if you want to ensure the initial print is water proof.  I would also recommend more top and side layers.

description.text: This is based on Pythagoras' original design. Until the cup is filled above the center pillar it will hold the liquid. As soon as the cup is filled too full, it will siphon the water through the hole in the bottom of the cup and out the bottom of the stem.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed this model originally at only 15% infill. There were spots in the bottom of the cup area where there were unwanted holes. Because of this I coated the inside of the cup with food safe silicone. I would recommend a higher infill, possibly even as high as 50% if you want to ensure the initial print is water proof. I would also recommend more top and side layers.

Pythagorean Chalice

I designed this piece in Fusion 360. The first step was to draw the overall outline of the cup as one half of a cross-section and then revolving that around the center axis. I then created a plane running vertically through the middle of the stem and drew the profile for the inner tubing. Finally, I used the sweep function in Fusion 360 to sweep a circular tube along the drawn path. This tube runs from the bottom of the stem all the way into the top of the center pillar and then back down into the cup where it again opens.

Pythagoras the trickster This is based on Pythagoras' original design. Until the cup is filled above the center pillar it will hold the liquid. As soon as the cup is filled too full, it will siphon the water through the hole in the bottom of the cup and out the bottom of the stem.
Fluid Dynamics and siphoning The cup demonstrates basic elements of fluid dynamics as the entirety of the cup is siphoned out through the bottom when, and only when the cup is filled too tall.
Obviously not for climbing, but this mini (~57 x 35mm) figure-8 will work as a large pull for a zipper, velcro, or just a cord; as a place to clip d-rings; or many other uses.

title: Apple Fanboy - Wireless Dock for iPhone + Apple Watch + AirPods

description.text:
This is a combination iPhone/ Apple Watch/ AirPods charger.

  • The iPhone charger is Wireless (Qi) using the dyi Qi part you can find here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B073W7P5T8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

You'll also need a micro-USB cable with a slim connector. I bought these, also from Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M0LK2SK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

It uses a standard Apple Lightning cable for the AirPods charging part and a standard Apple Watch charging puck for the Apple Watch.

I highly recommend printing with the highest resolution available as I designed it with tight tolerances for a good finish.

The screw holes are small to allow for drilling/adapting to whatever screws you want to use. I am using flat-head M1 torx screws.

The photos here are of the one I made and I spent a lot of time on post-processing (sand-blasting with glass beads, sanding and painting).

I still haven't printed the cover shown in the renders, but the idea is that the cables can be tucked inside the cover and whole thing becomes travel-friendly.

I braided the 3 cables to make it tidier.

I will soon post a video with assembly instructions.

Enjoy!

title: 40mm Fan Cover (20mm and 10mm Height)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
40mm Fan Cover

By Wiley Kyoto

This fan cover is designed to work with the 40mm Noctua fans, both 10mm and 20mm high. It will probably work for most other brand fans though. This is purely for aesthetics, as I didn't like the beige colour of the fan body. I didn't make a grill as I didn't want to restrict airflow, but I will probably upload a version with a grill. Especially if there's some requests for it.

This has a 0.2mm tolerance around the fan body, providing a loose friction fit. The screw holes are purely for access, not to hold it in place. There's a small notch on one side for the wires to come out. The thickness of the part is 1.4mm, so I recommend printing with 0.35 line thickness with no less than 2 shells. I printed it with a layer height of 0.175mm. I also recommend printing this upside down, so you don't need any supports.

author: EastJesus

description.text: this is a drive train for frc. you could print it if you want

Here is a work in progress. The goal was to create a cover for the huge holes on the back of the 63mm sk3 motors (6354, 6364, or 6374). But why have a cover when you could make a fan to help cool the motors? I have yet to test the fluid dynamics of how the fan helps, but it seems to help on my first tests. Im using these in a dual surf rods setup, so im really tight on space. The cover doesn't stick out past the cans button, so with the right 3mm screws nothing will stick out past the and of the axle. There are two fans uploaded of each design so determine which side your motor will be mounted and get the corresponding fan. (one is designed for turning left and one right). here are the specs for each design:
make sure you align the fan correctly, the cut outs should match the motor as well as have the screw holes line up.

Design v1.1
-30 blades mounted in a Backward-curved way so rocks are deflected off when spinning. the gap for a rock to get in is only 3.28mm by 5.2mm.
-Just needs about 10-12 grams of plastic and would probably be better to use a higher temp plastic. (Im just using regular PLA and will see how that works)
-needs 4 3mm screws between 4 and 10mm long (any longer and will hit windings)
very strong design, less obstruction of holes on back of motor... only positive is less stringing of filament on your 3D printer

Design v2.1
-52 blades mounted in a Backward-curved way so rocks are deflected off when spinning. The gap for a rock to get in is only 1.7mm by 5.2mm on these blades.
-Just needs about 10-12 grams of plastic and would probably be better to use a higher temp plastic. (Im just using regular PLA and will see how that works)
-needs 4 3mm screws between 4 and 10mm long (any longer and will hit windings)
This is a very good air flow fan, won't let any rocks in and is strong enough to take a few hits without breaking

Design V2.2 recommended
-52 blades mounted in a Backward-curved way so rocks are deflected off when spinning. The gap for a rock to get in is only 1.7mm by 7.2mm on these blades.
-Just needs about 10 grams of plastic and would probably be better to use a higher temp plastic. (Im just using regular PLA and will see how that works)
-needs 4 3mm screws between 4 and 10mm long (any longer and will hit windings)
this is the design with the best airflow, but least strong so don't use if you have underside mounted Sk3 motors

Design v3.1 recommended if space isn't an issue
-52 blades mounted in a Backward-curved way so rocks are deflected off when spinning. The gap for a rock to get in is only 1.7mm by 7.4mm on these blades.
-Just needs about 12 grams of plastic and would probably be better to use a higher temp plastic.
-needs 4 3mm screws between 6 and 12mm long (any longer and will hit windings)
This is the design with the best airflow, and also just as strong as the others. It does extend to the end of the axle though so its better where space isn't a concern

title: Configurable Angled Filament Feed for Dry Box

description.text:
Update 2018.03.05

I added a jig to help drilling the hole at a 45degree angle. Note that when you drill a hole through your plastic box, be very careful that you don't crack it. I would start with a pilot hole first and then make sure that a sharp wood drill is used instead of a dull sheet metal or masonry drill bit. And drill slowly to avoid cracking the case.

Use a 11mm or 7/16 drill bit with the jig to drill the right sized-hole at an angle.

Also added 13mm hole version for 1/2" drills.

I redid an eariler design I did for my filament dry boxes and decided to make it flexible and angled.

The original minimalist design was in https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2737593.

That still works but I wanted an angled feed and I want to have more flexible connectors to the teflon filament tubes.

If you want a simple feed, use the original minimalist design. If you want something fancy, this one should let you configure several different fittings with the various parts you can use.

Note : It works best at 0.875mm layer height for monoprice select mini or 0.1mm for CR-10. At 0.175mm for monoprice select mini, the threads will be tighter and needs more force to assemble. the M6 threads will be too tight and needs lots of force to insert. the fitting the pneumatic fittings.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

33

Notes:
  1. A short PTFE tube can be fed through the insert to reduce friction.
  2. Should be airtight if you tighten it properly. The minimum you need is the insert, the angled adapter and the lockring. A short PTFE tube recommended if you have one.
  3. There are optional couplers to add M6 or M10 pneumatic fittings.
  4. Note that the pneumatic fitting adapters often have some stringing in the middle due to the impossible overhang in the middle, but this is OK, just make sure to clean them.
  5. All can be printed without any support or raft. However the angled insert will have some stringing due to the 45deg angle, depending on how well tuned your printer is, you may need to clean them up before you can install the lockring. You could rotate it so the threads point straight up and add support but it should work as is.

I printed on the monoprice select mini at 0.0875mm layer height. I also tested a 0.1mm setting with CR-10 mini and a Qidi X-one. I tried PLA+ and ABS and they both work.

The example shown is using eSun PLA+ fire engine red and it is slightly more flexible than normal PLA.

If you are on a rush and don't care about the text, everyhting still works printed up to 0.175mm, but note that the M6 threads will be very tight and needs some force to insert.

Depending on your retraction settings and how well you calibrated your printer there is a chance that some stringing may show up at the threads of the angled insert.

Snip them off and it should work well.

comments.text: I've printed out several of these after having done your standard ones, which work great. However I'm having a lot of trouble getting these to insert into even a 1/2 inch opening. The threads go through fine but when it gets to the thicker piece behind them it gets hung up. How did you do the holes to get them to line up so flush?
comments.author: Battle_bovine

comments.text: You need a bigger drill.  It is also possible to use a 1cm drill and try to drill in at a 45degree angle using a jig, but the hole needs to be bigger.  Note that when drilling through plastic boxes, be careful that you don't crack them.  Use sharp drills meant for wood and go slowly and don't force it.  (I cracked one when I was in a hurry).
comments.author: Battle_bovine

comments.text: Snazzy, thank you! I did manage to get the fittings into my current boxes after a good bit of filing and ended up using some poster tack to help make an airtight seal around the opening. I've got some forstener bits that I might try as well since I don't have a single drill bit large enough.

title: Gibson Flying V mini guitar model

description.text:
Electric Guitar model based on Gibson Flying V. STL file is more or less 1:1 scale. For printing I've used 0,35 scale factor, in my opinion it give best results. 0.2 layer for body and 0.1 layer is ok.
Neck is divided in 2 pieces for easier printing. Neck head is flat, so it's good to bend it a little bit using heat. Priniting in ABS give possibility to smooth surface with acetone for better appearance.
For painting I've used acrylic model paints. Stings may be made by any thread, and glued to bridge.
I'm guitar music lover. I like this kind of decoration, I hope you like it too!
I'm going to make my private most famous and legendary guitar collection.

No

comments.text: Beautiful model!  How hard would it be to split it into parts that could be printed in different colors instead of painting?  What software would you suggest to do such a thing?
comments.author: LASERMAN

comments.text:
I don't have idea how to print in multimaterial. I'm mono printer :) You will need at least 4 colours.
It's my first painted model, and it's not so hard like it seems to be. I also made some features for easy painting like a little bit overhigh frets etc.
comments.author: LASERMAN

comments.text: I really wasn't talking about multi-color prints.  I was talking about making the parts separate so you could print them separately using a mono printer.  like separating the pick guard,  knobs, pickups, etc as separate files.  Check out the Dilbert model - that guy did a beautiful job.    Actually, I have produced multi-color models like yours by pausing at a certain height and changing material.  Most machines have a "pause at z" function so you can really be precise on when you switch.
comments.author: MalinaPl

comments.text: Ok, now I got. In my opinion in this scale splited parts, will be to small. It will be hard to assemble them well. Of course it's possible, but my goal was to avoid many parts, supports and glue ony where is necessary. Easier way is just to paint it. I made design in Fusion 360 and it's really easy to split body in to any parts. I don't know how to split STL model file. You can always import STL to any cad program you are using and then try to split inside software.

author: MakerBot

description.text:
Hard to describe, easy to use. This is a quick jig to hold wooden batons 7mm away from both edges of a plywood piece. I use plywood and batons to make my boxes, and being able to quickly space it a wall thickness away helps enourmously.

I use a nailgun, which makes it harder than just clamping, since you have to flip the piece over in order to drive the nails into the flat side. Making sure the batons are exactly 7mm from the edge is tricky without clamping, and if you clamp it then you can't lay the wood flat on the table, which makes alignment trickier. This jig holds the batons in place while you're flipping the wood. (Or rather it gives you reference edges to push the wood up to).

The roller-specific part associated with the tesselating cat pattern. The cat tessellation is based on a design by Makoto Nakamura. Polygon point locations were guessed from a surface plot of a thresholded greyscale version of the image.

See also https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:900766

author: FPV_Pilot

description.text:
This is a remake of robaux's LOL Clock (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219658). A new back piece 18mm thinner than the original has holes for the power socket and buttons.
A new circuit design has been done that uses two LED constant current drivers and five MOSFETs row drivers. There are two PCBs. One to hold all the LEDs (board is cut in half so that it can go in the case) and the second board holds the Arduino Mini, DS1307 RTC, DC-DC Buck convertor, Constant current LED drivers/shift registers and some buttons to set the time.
All Eagle files and Arduino sketch have been included along with the new back STL file. I made my boards using the toner method. The board contains SMD components because that is what I had on hand.
.................................
To set the time:
Press the MODE button, the hours will flash 5 times a second
Use the UP and DOWN buttons to set the hours
Press the MODE button, the minutes will flash 5 times a second
Use the UP and DOWN buttons to set the minutes
Press the MODE button and the normal time mode is shown. (denoted by the colon separator flashing once a second).

China pot China pot
This is a magical ancient Chinese pot, As you look it, it has not a cover, then, how water is going in?
Secret in the pot's Bottom! In the bottom, there's a tube, straight through to the top of the pot, the water is from here.
So, when adding water, will not leak from the spout it? will not!
Because the spout has another tube to extend along the kettle side of the pot, only the water diffuse through the nozzle, will be out of water.
Fill the water upside down, no water out.
Hold the pot, tilt, in order to pour out the water, as we usually pour the same water.
So why water can come out? If the jug is sealed, atmospheric pressure does not allow water to come out.
At this point, the inlet pipe to play the role of connecting the atmosphere, this time it became the inlet!
What a magical pot ,how interesting!
It is said that Chinese scientists at that time in order to find out its principles, a lot of effort, because you can not see it inside and you can not break it .It is an artifact！
倒流壶
这是一个神奇的中国古代的壶，粗看，它没有壶盖，那么，水是怎么进去的呢？秘密在壶底！壶底有一根管，直通壶顶，水就是从这里进去的。
那么，进水的时候，不会从壶嘴漏出来吗？不会！
因为壶嘴又有一要管沿着壶侧伸到壶底，只有水漫过管口，才会出水。
加满水后，将壶倒置，没有水出来。
握住壶把，倾斜，才能倒出水，就象我们平时倒水一样。
那么为什么水能出来呢？如果壶是密封的，大气压是不允许水出来的。
此时，进水管就起到连通大气的作用，此时它又成了进气口！
多么神奇！
据说，当时中国科学家为了搞清它的原理，费了不少功夫，因为，你看不到它内部，又不能打开它，因为它是文物。

title: Top piece replacement for Logitech g600 Mouse

description.text: if you want to replace the Top part of your G600 Mouse for whatever reason (mine melted in a fire, blocking the right click), print this as a replacement, i tested it over and over, it should work.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Rotate the Mouse 135° around x axis so that the palm of the mouse is on the bottom, scale by 1000% add Support only where touching buildplate

Replacement instruction

There are 4 screws below the pads on the bottom of the mouse, loosening those you can lift the top half, then loosen the ribbon cable and unscrew the top plastic part with the screws that go from the inside to the top part, then exchange that part with this, and screw it in, reattach the ribbon cable, close the mouse again and check if all mouse buttons work, pressing each in should make a sound, if the sound only appears from lifting the mousebutton, you can maybe grind down the part of the printed piece that should touch the button inside a bit. however hopefully it should work out of the box

Modeling Mice replacement parts

Take the mouse appart,
take pictures of the mouse from top, left, right, front and back, ideally from far away with heavy zoom, add them as Background images into Blender, start modeling with the important stuff, where the mouse pieces get attached or press Buttons, then the edges, then form a body freely and from that point on prototype over and over again.

title: Pressure Engine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is a project that has been put on hold, as the new semester is here and I don't have time to devote to this. The engine is designed to run off pressurized gas. The model is currently missing the fly wheel, clips to hold the case together, screws for head cylinder and block, and in order for it to work as intended there needs to be an O-ring and ball bearing within the head to create a one-way check value. Depending on your printer and plastic there may be a need for piston rings too. Even with the missing parts, I see this model as a way to learn, and think that it could be used to help teach the most basic functions of an engine, and with some more effort and time, this model has potential to become a functional engine. Again, this is a proof of concept, and is not complete. If you have any questions or any requests, feel free to leave a comment. Thanks, and I wish well to all those heading back to school and such after this much needed Christmas break.

print_settings.Notes:: Set the line stroke to minimum width

description.text:
This hook is used to attach 1" webbing to a fixed point. The fixed point should be a small sewn loop of 1" webbing. It works just like a normal "ladder lock" style adjuster, except the fixed end is easily and securely removable.

This type hook is usually made of steel (a la ITW G-Hook) or aluminum (a la Metolius Crash Buckle). The ITW version is very heavy, and the Metolius is reasonably priced, but impossible to find with reasonable shipping. You can find these inexpensively if you buy in bulk from alibaba.

I plan to plasma cut this from aluminum as a first go, if that fails, then I'll mill it on a small cnc. Some things will need adjusting to mill with an 1/8" bit, though.

After it's cut, it should be bent like the metolius buckle to increase the locking power. https://www.metoliusclimbing.com/crash_buckle.html

Notes:

Set the line stroke to minimum width allowed by your software. In Inkscape that is .001px. I believe Illustrator has a "minimum" setting. I didn't set the stroke width to that for the downloads because the part often disappears from the view that setting.

Originally drawn using FreeCAD on linux. I spent a couple hours with the tutorials. Then a few iterations cribbing from a an example buckle intended for 3/4" (20mm) webbing this was the result after a weekend.

print_settings.Notes:: Used Cura software, Printed with HEP plastic because that's what works best for me right now. description.text:
Ebay sells these 608 bearings cheap, but I've been waiting 2 months for them. Since I'm thinking of using them on a simple slow spool roller base with 1kg spools, I didn't think they would need a real steel or ceramic bearing, so I designed one in fusion 360.

It basically works but don't use them for heavy loads or continuously moving devices --- they won't last long.

This needs support but no raft to print. I tried 0.175mm layer height in monoprice select mini and 0.2mm on a CR-10. Either layer height will work.

I used infill of 33% just in case.

author: COLOR3DJP

description.text:
This project was a small test in learning screw thread tolerances and making a simple gear in fusion 360. A simple gravity-fed pin, sloped on one side illustrates how ratcheting mechanisms work under a relatively simple principle->make motion easy in one direction and difficult in another. The shape of the pin is sloped at one side to allow it to "ride" up on the saw-tooth gear teeth when rotated counter-clockwise, but two vertical edges meet at a parallel when trying to move clockwise, stopping the movement.
Hope you enjoy :).

If the pin is getting stuck, filing it down on the edges should help it move freely. Some super glue can help hold the body on the base if the parts are a loose fit (so far I have not needed any glue).
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQWvB4m48go&feature=youtu.be

title: Lithophane Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a work in progress.

A basic Lithophane cube style stand designed for a 3dp.rocks generated 100x100 Lithophane with a 4mm border and default thickness settings. Also included is a 100x150 version (taller). It's designed to use LED strips, but the central hole is large enough for some candelabra type light sockets.

The central pillar is removable and can be rotated to orient the LED strips towards either the sides, or the corners, and can be hot glued into place when happy.

There is a cover that can be cut away if you would like to include an On/Off switch, or can be left in place if you prefer not to have a switch.

It's designed to use Drofnas's excellent Barrel to DC Adapter Holder
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2518532 which fits snug in a recessed cutaway and can be hot glued into place.

There are recesses on the top and pillars if you want to use magnets to help keep the top on.

Please note, some assembly required. LED light strips will require some soldering.

Possible Accessories:
LED Light Strip: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005ST2I9O/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

12v Female Adapter: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01J1WZENK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

12v Wall Adapter: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FEOB4EI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

On/Off Switch: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0147XECOU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Turantula RPi Mount on MKS + Mosfet Control Box

You will need:

  • 4x M4*8mm screw
  • 4x M4 Nuts

Steps for mounting:
Step 1: Insert nuts into first mount, slide the mount DOWNWARDS into the last vent at the back of MKS box
Step 2: Screw on the second mount to the top of the RPi box
Step 3: Insert the RPi box mount into the second vent and slide UPWARDS. At this point, you should be able to align the holes for the bottom screws, and insert the other screws.

title: eBike/Universal Voltmeter and Ammeter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Unless you have a smart charger for your eBike, it's hard to know when the battery is charged.
This is a small Voltmeter/Ammeter, designed to go between battery and charger to tell the voltage and amps being delivered.

It can also be used in between battery and motor/controller to show remaining charge. Although I havent designed any mounts for it to go on the bike

Can be used in any project where measuring 30-100V is needed up to 3A

Based on simple $3 Voltage Current indicators from china, 2x 18650 cells and a small charging circuit. A switch and any connectors you like/need.

  1. Voltage/Current indicator
  2. Micro USB 18650 charger board
  3. Battery spring and plate set
  4. Mini SPST Rocker Switch
  5. 6x 6-12mm M3 screws

Wiring is completed partially by the included diagram.

IMPORTANT!
The reason this project is powered by the 18650 cells is because these Voltmeter/Ammeters run on 4-30V DC.

Note: The display can be off (using the switch) and it will not disrupt power flow.

Because I am measuring beyond 30V DC (Most eBikes are 36V-60V) the power from the charger CANNOT be used to power the display, it must come from another alternate source.

The SMALL red and black lines go to the 18650 charger board outputs (5V)
The SMALL yellow line taps into the RED line that is coming IN and OUT
The LARGE red and black lines intersect the BLACK line that is coming IN and OUT.

When I get time (or requests), I will draw up the diagram properly, but from the photos and included diagram, and if you are into eBikes, you are likely savvy enough to wire it up very easily

Printer:

Wilson 2

description.text:
I designed this phone dock to be clipped onto the bottom of a cars center console, making it possible to quickly connect my phone to my car with one hand. If you have Apple Car Play or Android Auto this is ideal as you don't need to interact with your phone once it is connected to the car.
The intention was to create a mounting point without having to drill into the center console or dashboard of the car, however stick on velco may be required on the back in order to create firm grip to cars carpet if the dock is slipping down.
The hole for the cable is centrally located at the base. In my case the cable is thick enough to be wedged in between the clip part (see photo), this prevents the cable from moving when connecting and disconnecting phone.

Internal dimensions for phone = 80mm (wide) x 15mm (thick)
Cable opening = 13mm x 7mm
Space between main body and rear arm = 6mm

title: Bed Flatness test model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you want to know exactly how crooked your glass, mirror and the aluminum bed are, or if your X gantry is not in perfect level, run this test.

edit: Be sure to level the bed as you usually do before running this. You can use this to level the bed and you will try to adjust as its working but it takes at least an hour for the first layer. Its better if the bed is already leveled. i recommend and use Tacblades Easy leveling: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gkZUAyTxU1Q

Both models are the same, one just has small empty triangles in the middle to be more fancy. (it will also show you how precise your printer is) Both are 295 in diameter, but you can increase or decrees the size in your slicer, if you want to.

Models are 1mm thick and you choose the layer height and other settings yourself as it fits your usual printing practice. Usually one layer is enough to see the discrepancies, but sometimes they show up only on subsequent higher layers.

As the lines fill up run a finger over them. If you notice the surface is rough in some places, as if its sanded, thats where your bed is too high, or nozzle too low. If the distortion in bigger you will get small rough piles and "hills" of plastic, sometimes looking like tentacles spreading across the lines direction.

Any dips in the printing surface will make the lines first look slightly separated and then peal off.

The thing is... the setup of CR 10 mechanics and materials makes it so that all the aluminum beds distort and bend, even if they were mostly flat at the start, and the glass and mirrors follow along, with all the heating and cooling and bending on the four corners.

The more you print, the worse it all gets.

Have a nice day.

...

...

p.s.
I am now on a quest to solve this conundrum and achieve perfect flatness!

After converting my mill to CNC, I have a few 17mm speed handles laying around and I thought it might be nice to use one on my vise, so I whipped up this little adapter to connect the 17mm speed handle to the 1/2" hex bolt on the vise.

The press fit is pretty solid, but I use an 8mm bolt and a fender washer to ensure the adapter stays on the speed handle.
Tired of searching for your usb cable under the lack table beside your bed? Well, no more. This maze-like usb cable holder allows you to keep them in place and within the arm distance.

title: Centreurs de tiges T8 & M8 pour Dagoma DiscoEasy & DiscoVery

description.text:
2018-02-10 - Merci à Chikungunya pour ses vidéos :

Il s'agit ici d'un remix des pièces suivantes :

  • Centrages hauts avec roulement et renforts : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2538950

  • Anti-ondulation XYZ du coupleur souple 5x8 : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2537196

Ce remix a été fait pour permettre l’utilisation de vis Trapézoïdales T8,
en implémentant des roulements a guidage long avec serrages intégrés.
Ces roulements permettent aussi l’usage de tiges filetés M8. Ils apportent alors un bien meilleur guidage que les pièces originales que j’avais précédemment partagées.

Dans le cas de l'utilisation de la tête 3 ventilos, la course Z est ici ré-augmenter à 220 mm grâce aux centreurs hauts.

Ensemble des centreurs Haut

  • 4 x vis M3 – 10 (serrage tiges horizontales)
  • 14 x vis M3 – 12
  • 4 x rondelles M3
  • 18 x écrous M3
  • 2x roulements KFL pour montage à plat : 8 mm (1er choix) : https://www.banggood.com/810121517mm-Bore-Diameter-Zinc-Alloy-Pillow-Block-Flange-Bearing-KFL-Series-p-1119328.html

Ensemble des centreurs Bas (Anti-ondulation XYZ du coupleur souple 5x8)

  • 4 x vis M3 – 12
  • 4 x vis M3 – 18 (ou plus long, pour la fixation du roulement)
  • 4 x rondelles M3
  • 8 x écrous M3
  • 2x roulements KP pour montage latéral KP08 (3eme choix) : https://www.banggood.com/8mm-to-35mm-KP-Series-Bore-Diameter-Mounted-Ball-Bearings-Zinc-Alloy-Pillow-Block-Housing-p-1076413.html

Tiges filetées M8 ou trapézoïdales T8

  • longueur utile 320 mm (ou plus)
  • Pour information, j’utilise 2x tiges trapézoïdales T8 rectifiées de 400 mm (recoupées à 320 mm), ayant la référence suivante. Cette référence inclut des Roulements KP08 pour montage latéral, ainsi que des coupleurs de précision: https://www.banggood.com/T8-400mm-Stainless-Steel-Lead-Screw-Set-with-Mounted-Ball-Bearing-and-Shaft-Coupling-p-995052.html

Printer:

Dagoma Disco Z122

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30 %

Notes:

Résolution :

  • 200 um pour les centreurs bas,
  • 100 um ou 150 um pour les centreurs hauts, + supports

Épaisseur des murs: 1.2 mm

Instructions pour un bon montage

Avant le montage :

  • Desserrer (sans dévisser totalement les fixations des 2 moteurs Z)
  • Détendre la courroie de l’axe X
  • Si vous utilisez des tiges trapézoïdales, desserrer légèrement les fixations des écrous des chariots afin de les rendre libres.

Consignes pour le montage :

  • Pré-monter l’ensemble des pièces en ne serrant pas totalement les vis de fixations des roulements KFL (du haut) et KP (du bas) afin de les rendre libres. Ils seront resserrés plus tard.
  • Monter les tiges (trapézoïdales ou M8) en dernier en venant les glisser par le dessus jusque dans les coupleurs (non serrés), à travers les écrous des chariots Z
  • Lever manuellement (par rotation des tiges) les 2 chariots Z a une hauteur moyenne (environ Z= 150 mm). Si vous constater alors un jeu horizontal dans les tiges X, veiller à mettre des cales pour supprimer ce jeu. Puis re-tendre la courroie X. Bouger (monter/baisser manuellement) les chariots Z pour vérifier que les paliers coulissent bien.
  • Descendre les chariots Z au plus bas. Dans cette position, commencer par serrer les vis de fixations des roulements KP (du bas). Puis, si vous avez des tiges trapézoïdales, resserrer les vis de fixation des écrous trapézoïdaux. Et enfin, serrer les petites vis (sans tête) au centre des roulements KP.
  • Lever les chariots Z au maximum de leur course (toujours en tournant manuellement les tiges Z). Dans cette position, serrer les vis de fixations des roulements KFL (du haut), puis serrer les vis sans tête au centre de ces roulements.
  • Redescendre manuellement les chariots Z, resserrer les coupleurs. Puis – et en dernier – resserrer les vis de fixations des moteurs.
Fusion 360

title: Baroque Alto Recorder in F rmx

description.text:
Hitoprl created a great alto recorder, witch I like much. Is has a baroque fingering also known as modern English fingering.
As I printed it, I found some details I want to change or improve:

  • The recorder was tuned on F with A = 440Hz, but only when it is cold. When it is warm it is a litte to high. Our other records are tuned slightly below 440Hz. So the remix will be tuned a little lower.
  • The lower notes like F are hard to play. The food piece should have a redesign.
  • The windway of the mouthpiece was very narrow, hard to print & play. It should be wider and moved very little to the outside.

This is a redesign of the scad file and all relevant parts in respect of the described requirements.
The stl and the amf file including a compensation for to small printed holes of 0.3mm. In the scad file you could change this.

Please print with layer height of 0.16mm or smaller.

After printing you have to do the same as decribed in the original "thing":

  • Remove the supports in the central bore of some parts.
  • Sharpen the labium,
  • upper mouthpiece: put a chamfer at the lower end of the windway.

For more information please consider the original thing
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:956851
and Hitoprl's very good instructions at
http://www.instructables.com/id/Baroque-Alto-Recorder-in-F/

I hope you like it!

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Resolution:

0.16 or smaller

Infill:

20%

Notes:

author: vadymch

description.text:
Here's my charger and battery tester designed to be super cheap. It uses 5 tp4056 modules (2$ for all) and two ZB2L3 modules for testing the capacity. The circuit has been done to easily swap between charging and testing using the same battery slots. Of course the testing/charging function is only available on two slots (thats because there are only two ZB2L3). To create this easily charging and testing function you just need to use a toggle switch connecting the positive side of the battery holder to the "common" of the toggle: on one of the other side of the toggle goes the positive of the tp4056, to the last pin of the toggle will go instead the positive side of the input of ZB2L3. The ground negative of the battery holder and the negative of the ZB2L3 and the negative of the tp4056 are connected together.
Last note: the holes of the ZB2L3 are missing because some of the measure may vary, making those holes is super easy and shouldn't be a problem.

The LED strip requires a simple 2 pin AC (220V) connection and voila! my print bed is all light and I can see my models being printed...

This is a remix of the case for Anet LCD 12864 by Leo_N. I needed to have the display on top of the printer at an angle and this is working fine on my AM8 3Dprinter.

This display has a limited viewing angle and I find it difficult to read outside the "sweet spot" so that's why it isn't just 90 degrees and flush with the top bar.

Please note that this LCD has two PCBs inside and on my display they were just soldered together with the connector. Anet have provided mounting holes for screws,but are not using them. You should add M3 screws and nuts to prevent vibrations/noise caused by these two PCBs. I have provided some spacers you can use between the two boards (with the same length as the height of the connector on my screen). Use these so you don't overtighten the screws and break the PCB.
Update 13.01.2018
Uploaded a new version that should be completely flush with the front of the 2020 extrusion. The depth of the outer casing has been reduced by 2mm. No other changes!

Update 21.01.2018
Published some simple spacers. Please note that there may be variations in production of the LCD-screen and you might need a diiferent length. The published spacer should be 2,85mm high

title: 40.5mm filter wrench for the Sony PZ 16-50 OSS lens

description.text:
I recently bought a Sony a6000 camera with its PZ 16-50 OSS 'kit lens'. It is my habit to put a UV filter to protect the front of my lenses but, in this case, the odd-sized 40.5mm filter decided to stick in the camera lens's thread (not an uncommon occurrence with filters). Normally it is easy to get hold of a filter and unscrew it, but in this case the filter is much smaller than the lens body diameter and it proved impossible to get a decent grip.

There are some designs for filter wrenches in Thingiverse, but none for this odd size, so I designed my own in OpenSCAD. It was made over-sized so that a thin rubber sheet can be inserted between the filter and the wrench to give extra grip - alternatively, an elastic band can be fitted around the filter to do the same job. The aim is to give an even grip around the filter body, rather than allowing excessive force; you should find that a firm grip on the handles will give a positive hold on the rim and the filter should unscrew will little effort.

It's not a 'pretty' design - it's functional and intended to do a specific job without fuss. The OpenSCAD file is tiny, and hopefully has enough comments to allow anyone to make changes.

author: TueftelTyp

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with 10% infill for weight reasons, feel free to adjust if concerned about rigidity and strength while spinning.

description.text:
Needed a 3 blade spinner for my FT Spitfire but wasn't able to find one that would fit so made my own and sharing here for anyone that wants to try it or modify it (included .skp file). Images included are of Spinner Base 2 and Spinner Top 2 fitted to the FT Spitfire and a 8040x3 prop.

This spinner is designed to fit on a 4mm propshaft however can be drilled out to fit larger shafts if needed. M4 screws (4mm thread diameter) are needed to fasten the top to the base, ideal length would be 10mm to get enough grip but avoid prop contact.

Modeled primarily for a 8040x3 prop but has a large tolerance for other props (especially Base 1). If you're unsure which is best for you or want to modify the design you can load them up in Sketchup (or your preferred editor) and measure/modify aspects to fit your prop.

Spinner Base 2 is probably the better one to print as it's got less unnecessary spacing in for the props however if you're unsure your prop will fit Base 2 then try the Base 1 will probably be best.

Creality CR-10

Printed with 10% infill for weight reasons, feel free to adjust if concerned about rigidity and strength while spinning.

author: sety

description.text:
This file is a DXF of FRC Team 587's 2017 off season project. We wanted to know if we could design a single chassis plate that could accept any of the four available 3 CIM shifting gear boxes available through AndyMark and Vex Robotics. The answer is yes!

Furthermore, the gearboxes mount assembled meaning they can be swapped out by removing a couple screws, disconnecting a few wires and dropping out the bottom of the bot. (We had output shaft failures last year so we wanted to be able to replace them quickly should that happen again.)

Do we need that much power and speed? Probably not, but it sure is fun to have it available!

title: Customizeable Cooling Fan Blades
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 2:

There is now another update that aims at recreating the original blades even more accurate. Therefore I introduced a second bending for the blades. Because the blades are now a surface bent in all three dimensions, the rendering of the model is everything but trivial. Using OpenSCAD to render takes depending on the settings more than 20 minutes! If you don't want to wait that long, you can use the previous file Customizeable_Fan_Blades.scad instead of the new one Customizeable_Fan_Blades_Advanced.scad. Another way to render the model faster is using a server based online service instead of a local OpenSCAD installation.

Furthermore I changed from setting an angle to influence the strength of the bowing to setting the bowing radius.

The variables are all explained in the comments in detail, so please read them carefully if you don't understand something, feel free to ask.

Update 1:

Just uploaded an update. The blades itself are now perpendicular to the center circle over their entire size which should optimize the air flow a little bit.

Explanation:

Since I broke of many blades of my original 40mm fan by accident, I thought about repairing it with 3D printed parts which is much cheaper than buying a replacement since the printed blades only cost a few cent.

Although such things have already been made, none of them matched my expectations, because I want to replace the whole blade part and not just the blades itself to keep the full area for the airflow and I wanted the fan to be customizeable to a large extend to be able to even optimize the fan and adjust everything to my specific needs.

Because of this I created my own fan blades design which is mostly customizeable using the following parameters:

  • Overall_Thickness: The thickness of the whole part.
  • Outer_Diameter_Blades: The diameter of the complete fan with blades.
  • Thickness_Blades: The thickness of the blades perpendicular to their surface.
  • Amount_Blades: The amount of blades in the whole fan.
  • Bowing_Blades: An angle to adjust how much the blades are bent.
  • Angle_Blades: The mean angle of the blades to the xy-plane.
  • Inner_Diameter_Body: The diameter of the inner hole where the magnetic ring is fitted into.
  • Thickness_Body: The thickness of the walls for the inner part of the blades.
  • Axle_Diameter: The diameter of the small hole the axle of the fan is fitted into.

The default values in the comments in the scad file are the values I measured on the original ANET fan blades using a caliper. Using these values I created the stl file supplied in the file section.

There are no restrictions on the parameters although some values might not give you a useable result. The preview does not work properly because of the large amount of vertices. You need to render the model to get a correct result, which takes some time.

Currently the model is designed for 40mm fans. The model can be customized to any other fan size using the customization parameters.

If you like it, you may also check out my other Anet A8 and 3d printing things:

  • Improved Customizeable Anet A8 E3Dv6 Mount with 40mm Fan Mount
  • Filament Guides for the Anet A8 in 6 variations (0°, 45°, 90°) Vertical and Horizontal
  • Anet A8 - Original X Axis Mounts V2
  • Linear Bushing / Bearing - LM8UU - IGUS like - with mount
  • Spoolhoder tube to lower rotational resistance (requires two axle bearings)
  • Cable Clip (Anet like)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The model is designed to be printed with a 0.4mm nozzle and a layer height of 0.2mm. Usally rafts or supports are not required although small Blade angles might require supports.

To replace the original part follow the following steps:

  1. Remove the sticker on the back of the fan.
  2. Behind the sticker you can see the axle mounted with a clamping ring which you have to remove.
  3. Afterwards you can take the blades out. Pliers might be helpful.
  4. Now you can remove the axle from the original blades which can be done using pliers too.
  5. Furthermore you have to remove the magnetic ring too. This can be done using a flat screw driver.
  6. Now you have to put the axle and the magnetic ring into the printed parts. A vise is really helpful for this.
  7. The last step is to put the blades back into the mount and secure them with the clamping ring on the axle.

Make sure that the blades can spin freely. If thats not the case check wether the axle is mounted 100% perpendicular and if something does not fit, adjust the corresponding parameter.

title: box with clip or magnetic lock, different versions

description.text:
This is a small box that is printed in one piece.
I designed it as a fly fishing box but it can be used for all kinds of stuff.
There are different versions, also without the trout on the cover, which are going to be updated since its a work in progress project.
There are basically two different boxes of the same size but with different lock mechanisms. The one has a clip and is ready to use after printing, there are no further materials need, except for the foam if you want.
The other one has a magnetic locking mechanism using 8 small 5x3x2mm neodym magnets.

01/14/2018
I added a few new files with reworked versions of the box.
The hinges on all box are different now and I changed the magnet version a bit.
There is also a new box with a shrimp on the cover.

The material needed for the magnet box:

  • 8x 5x3x2mm neodym magnets
  • superglue
  • selfadhesive foam sheet 2-5mm thick

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a brim of 10mm width to prevent the bottom plane from warping.

Supports are only needed for the magnet version.

Clip version

On the version with the clip you might have to smothen the contact surfaces of the clip mechanism to make it work smoothly.
I used a lighter to heat up the hollow where the clip catches and worked it a few times while it was still hot.
But be carefull, don't use too much heat.
Alternatively some sandpaper should work as well.

Magnetic version

Insert the magnets on one side of the box first, if the magnets sit in the pockets too loose use some superglue. I used small nose pliers to insert the magnets into the pockets.
After that place a second magnet on top of each inserted magnet and mark the side facing upwards.
This makes it easier to insert them on the other side with the right orientation.
Then repeat the whole process for the other side.

If you want to use the box for flyfishing you might want to attach a foam pad to both pieces.
Cut out two pieces 95x60mm and trimm the corners a little bit to make it fit.
I used selfadhesive foam sheets with a thickness of 2 and 5mm.

author: hknauer

description.text:
Electric Guitar model based on Fender Stratocaster. STL file is more or less 1:1 scale. For printing I've used 0,35 scale factor, in my opinion it give best results. 0.2 layer for body and 0.1 layer is ok.
To avoid supports, neck is divided in 2 pieces for easier printing. Priniting in ABS give possibility to smooth surface with acetone for better appearance.
For painting I've used acrylic model paints. Stings may be made by any thread, glued to bridge.
I'm guitar music lover. I like this kind of decoration, I hope you like it too!
I'm going to make my private most famous and legendary guitar collection.

Electronic Mounting Points for:

  • Anet A8 main board.

  • 2 MOSFET's.

  • 2 Slots for SD cards for Anet and Raspberry via microSD to SD extensions. I use SD cards because they are just easier to handle.

  • 7" Touch Screen.

    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/30-Amp-12-Volt-DC-13-8V-Regulated-Switching-Power-Supply-WHOLESALE-LOT-OF-10/362194768021?hash=item54547d9095:g:vQIAAOxyni9TD8h1

  • IEC Fuse Chassis Male Power Plug with Switch:
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/NEW-IEC-Fuse-Chassis-Male-Power-Plug-with-Switch-PP4003/252985807193?epid=904172097&hash=item3ae7211159:g:JAcAAOSw62VZxPNQ

  • Raspberry Pi 3 Model B - Premium NOOBS Pack:
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/Raspberry-Pi-3-Model-B-Premium-NOOBS-Pack-16GB-USB-Switch-2-5A-Power-Supply/201385350646?hash=item2ee38095f6:g:yJUAAOSwLEtYlUV6

  • M3 M4 M5 Hex Socket Screws Set (Only uses M3 ans M4 for PSU)
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/440pc-M3-M4-M5-Hex-Socket-Screws-Set-Stainless-Steel-Screws-and-Nuts-Repair-Tool/292191840569?hash=item4407fda939:g:FP4AAOSwTLxZhZLo

  • 0.5m USB 2.0 A To RIGHT ANGLE MICRO B (Power for screen from Raspberry + it's the touch input):
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/0-5m-USB-2-0-A-To-RIGHT-ANGLE-MICRO-B-Data-Charging-Cable-50cm-Lead-007239/382268609416?epid=1630600552&hash=item5900fc1388:g:n94AAOSw-jFaHdPI

  • 50cm USB A to B CABLE - Printer Scanner Cord (50cm seems to be the smallest cables go):
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/50cm-USB-A-to-B-CABLE-Printer-Scanner-Cord-Lead-Wire-Modem-USB-2-0-NEW-Short-/322968937423?

  • 50cm HDMI CABLE (50cm seems to be the smallest cables go)
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/50cm-HDMI-CABLE-v1-3-High-Speed-Digital-Full-HD-TV-Short-Cord-Lead-Male-0-5m-NEW-/322968951224?

  • HDMI Right Angle Male To Female 90-180 Degree (This is required because the space to plug into the screen is tight so the plastic case on this adapter needed to be removed to fit. I then covered it in heat shrink tubing.
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/HDMI-Right-Angle-Male-To-Female-90-180-Degree-Adapter-Cable-Lead-Connector-BDAU/362151940118?epid=2251233935&hash=item5451f01016:g:SSQAAOSwAO9ZSdwh

  • PUSH ON PUSH OFF BUTTON SQUARE:
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/2X-SPST-PUSH-ON-PUSH-OFF-BUTTON-SQUARE-SWITCH-BLACK/282348515537?hash=item41bd4870d1:g:1bkAAOSwCU1Y304D

  • SD to Micro SD Card Extension Cable Extender Adapter x2:
    https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/SD-to-Micro-SD-Card-Extension-Cable-Extender-Adapter-SDHC-For-Car-GPS-TV-CN-48cm/131978779662?epid=503010732&hash=item1eba8c5c0e:g:N2EAAOSw609Z32Jq

  • Any 80mm Fan.

Building:

Not that much to it really.
Infill and layer height are all up to the person printing.
All parts are laid out the way I printed them, feel free to position how you want.
All parts are able to fit on a 220x220 build plate.
Print out main body parts, glue or plastic weld together or how ever you want to join them.
The Lid and Front Panel parts get screwed on.

Outline effect.
If it's to confusing you don't have to do it just ignore all the FIRST LAYER ONLY files.
To get the outline of the Octoprint logo and edges in a different color print the part with the "First Layer Only" first don't remove from build plate then print the whole piece on top of it.
Same go's with the Anet logo.
Raspberry mounts on the under side of the back lid.

Octoprint with Touch UI set up:

I followed this guide to get all working:
https://github.com/BillyBlaze/OctoPrint-TouchUI/wiki/Setup:-Boot-to-Browser-(Jessie-Full)

comments.text: The push button switch turns the lights on and off. The raspberry is power by seperate power that came with it (http://projectshopbd.com/product/raspberry-pi-3-power-supply-5v-2-5a-power-supply-adapter-raspberry-pi-3-389/) and has a toggle switch on the power line that comes out the back. I use Wemo Insight wifi switch (http://www.belkin.com/au/p/P-F7C029/) to turn on and off and the system for that is installed on the raspberry then use octoprint command plugin to do the command to turn it on and off. So I haven't wired anything special. It's a pretty simple system.

title: Dime From Hell mini Guitar model

description.text:
Electric Guitar model based on Dean "Dime from hell" STL file is more or less 1:1 scale. For printing I've used 0,35 scale factor, in my opinion it give best results. 0.2 layer for body and 0.1 layer is ok.
To avoid supports, neck is divided in 2 pieces for easier printing. Neck head is flat, so it's good to bend it a little bit using heat. Priniting in ABS give possibility to smooth surface with acetone for better appearance.
I'm guitar music lover. I like this kind of decoration, I hope you like it too!
I'm going to make my private most famous and legendary guitar collection.

description.text:
This thing will add a 15 pin VGA connector to ebay Quick Release slim type for your simulator.
With vga 15 pin connector you can use the original cables plus an extra usb for a arduino card etc. so you can add buttons or a screen to your steeringwheel.

Print out in PLA or ABS
You will need to use a 6mm drill bit and make place for countersunk screws so they sit flush with the thing for the vga connectors, if not there will be no space for them.
Use 4 M3x8 Countersunk screws.
Use 4 M3 nuts to secure the 4 countersunk screws.
Use 2 M3x8 countersunk screws to connect wheelpart 1 & 2
If the screws dont fit when printed, drill with 2.5mm drillbit where wheelpart 1 and 2 will be screwed together, all other holes use 3mm drillbit.

To connect this to the Thrustmaster base, go to my basepart:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2781811

Shopping list:
  • ebay quick release slim type
  • Male and Female 15 pin VGA connectors solder type (RS232 serial connectors should also work)
  • 6 M3x8mm countersunk screws
  • 4 M3 nuts
  • wiring for the VGA connectors to the sim base and whatever you want to connect to your steering wheel, arduino for buttons, screen or whatever...
Update:
  • wheelpart 1 and hubpart is now ready for countersunk screws.
  • All files scaled correct (if you have the old files they need 1000% scale in cura)
  • Added a cable holder you can use instead of nuts on basepart, so you dont twist the cable, secure it with a ziptie

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print in PLA or ABS

description.text:
Pour plateau 300x300!
J'ai dessiné cet encadrement destiné à tenir la vitre supérieure sans utiliser les pinces. Elle est ainsi plus facile à déposer pour le nettoyage.
La hauteur des rebords a été calculée pour accepter un isolant coton de 3mm sous le plateau.

Du fait des épaisseurs supplémentaires, le fin de course Z doit être relevé, en modifiant les trous de fixation.
L'ensemble gauche permet la sortie du câble du lit chauffant, ainsi que le raccordement à ce guide câble: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2640692

///////////////////////°°°\\\\\\\\\\

Only for 300 x 300 bed!
I drew this heating bed frame to take off the top glass without using the pliers. It is thus easier for cleaning.
The edge height was calculated to accept a 3mm cotton insulation under the tray.

Because of the additional thicknesses, the Z endstop must be raised, by modifying the fixing holes.
The left set allows the cable outlet of the heating bed, as well as the connection to this cable guide: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2640692

Creality CR-10

description.text: I wanted to mount my microphone on a wall, so I designed this thing.

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Notes:

The supports are neccesary to generate the hollow structure underneath the mount to be able to mount this flat to a rough and bumpy surface. This is also why it is crucial to print at a high resolution, to be able to scrape off the support-structure with relative ease.

Finish

After removing the supports I started by sanding the model with 800 Grit sandpaper. Then I sprayed on a thin coat of Fillerprimer and wet sanded it with 1200 Grit Sandpaper. I repeated this procedure twice and sprayed on a thin coat of RAL 5015 paint for that shiny glossy skyblue finish.

Mounting

This thing was made for an 3/8" hexhead screw with a lenght of approximately 35mm. To mount this to a drywall I used M2.9x19 screw usually used for sheet metal.

title: LG Nexus 4 Dock Holder with audio and power access

description.text:
A landscape dock for an LG Nexus 4 phone with access ports for audio cable and USB power.

I needed a dock to hold the phone so it could be used as a Spotify front end controller, be permanently powered and also connected to the hi-fi with 3.5mm audio cables.

The dock has access for the power and audio, as well as a hole to press the sleep/lock button and a recess for the volume rocker so it won't activate once set in place. The phone sits nicely in the dock once the audio and USB are attached, I added a removable sticky dot to the rear to keep it extra secure as it won't be removed from in here.

The stand can be slotted and then glued into place which holds it at a nice angle similar to other docks. There is an optional front plate too which has a hold perfect to only show the screen, I prefer the look without this but the option is there. Suggest sticking this in place with double sided tape.

USB cable is a common right angled micro USB, the audio cable I used was this UGREEN flat cabled one:

https://www.amazon.co.uk/UGREEN-Headphones-Stereos-Smartphones-Speakers-Red/dp/B00SUIKMBQ

description.text:
EQ mount II for small telescope or DSLR, desing for OnStep goto controller.

FreeCAD sources on Github

EQ mount used 2x My Planetary geerbox 1024:1

More info about OnStep goto controller on Howard Dutton project or OnStep News

My OnStep Controller Box for on Arduino Mega2560 board.

OnStep config.XXX.h
              // Axis1 is for RA/Az
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis1  12288.0  // calculated as    :  stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * (gear_reduction2/360)
             // NEMA17 + PLANET   :  200  * 16  * 27/20   *  1024/360   = 12288.0
             // Axis2 is for Dec/Alt
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis2  12288.0   // calculated as    :  stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * (gear_reduction2/360)
             // NEMA17 + PLANET  :   200  * 16   * 27/20  * 1024/360    = 12288.0                                     
             // PEC, number of steps for a complete worm rotation (in RA), StepsPerDegreeAxis1*360)/gear_reduction2.  Ignored on Alt/Azm mounts.
#define StepsPerWormRotationAxis1 4320L   
             //  NEMA17 + PLANET  : (12288*360)/1024 = 4320

I printed stumphopper's wind gauge and was disappointed with two perceived flaws:

  • Plastic to plastic friction. A breeze wouldn't spin the gauge, only a gust, so I inserted a 608ZZ bearing to allow for smoother rotation.

  • Sagging arms. I live in Southern California. A sunny 82 degree day made the arms sag about 1/2 inch. A hot August day would probably fold the arms all the way down to the post. I used 5/16" wooden poplar rod from the hardware store instead of the plastic arms.
    • I removed the wind direction piece of the gauge because I don't care.

author: fedewolfie

description.text:
Litofania DRAGON BALL con tutorial

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6YxPL4pNb7w&t=40s

This is a complete construction of the Y axis on the 40x20 nut 5 A profile. The motor is a NEMA 17 with 22 mm flange, dimensions 42.3x42.3x39.2 mm, without shaft. The shaft is 22.6 mm long and has Ø 5 mm. The assembly mountet with M5x12mm screws 12 pieces, M3x12mm countersunk screws 4 pieces (motor mount), M3x24mm 1 piece and 2 self-tapping screws Ø2mm x10mm 2 pieces. First you screw the step motor to the holder, then you attach the holder with the motor to the A-profile and only afterwards you put the pinion on the shaft and adjust exact position.
The attachment of the toothed belt must ensure horizontal movement of the toothed belt to the motor and on the opposite side to the belt tensioner. The success of fixing under the hot bed at different heights. For me the height difference is 5mm

This is a very compact design that does not need any extra parts when using hot bed mount ANET and other 3D printers.
The engine is in contact with the A-profile, which ensures very good engine cooling.
The mounting of the motor is allowed from both sides of the bracket. The motor mount has a small feather key for the groove of the profile.
The motor mount must be printed as shown on the picture of CURA, so do not jiggle any hanging thread. My print speeds are for an A-frame printer, so correct the information so your printer can print it too.
The idea of ​​the development was, as economical as possible, to use the space and get by with a few parts.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:273099 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=273099

description.text: Tool for leveling you print bed on a CTC and similar printers. This is inspired by thing 30080 and thing 23257, but these did not fit the magnets I had at hand and only one of them had the source files needed to modify it - and I did not have access to that tool. So here is a version with the OpenJSCAD source file, so you can change it to fit your printer and the magnets you have at hand.

Printer:

CTC Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed this in ABS and simply used my normal setting for the ABS used. So if you already has a set of settings that work for you, just use these - there are no special requirements for this simple rig.

Designed using OpenJSCAD

I use Notepad++ to edit the file and OpenJSCAD for redering and to generate the STL.

If you want to modify the jig, just drop the file onto the field on https://openjscad.org/ and change the relevant constants at the top of the file:

ROD_DIA is the diameter of the X-axis rods on you printer (default 8mm)
ROD_DIST is the distance between the two rods (default 60mm)
CALIPER_DIA is the diameter of the caliper tube (default 8mm + 0.3mm tolerance)
MAG_DIA is the magnet diameter (default 12mm + 0.5 tolerance)
MAG_H is the height or thickness of the magnet (default 4mm)

author: mussy

print_settings.Notes:: Note: Top Layer fill should be set to as low as possible to prevent a blob forming onto the tip.

description.text:
As a person living in a country with strict gun laws i wanted to print some ammo in real scale just to get a better idea how big bullets and different type of ammo really is.

I made few of the more commonly known bullet types using as close as possible measures to the real world counterparts to make these as accurate as possible.

Includes:
5.56x45 NATO
7.62x39
7.92x57 Mauser
7.65×21 Parabellum
9x19 Parabellum
10mm AUTO
30-06 Springfield
40 S&W
45 ACP
308 Winchester
338 Lapua Magnum
500 S&W Magnum (The tip is suppose to be flat, but i made it round instead)
50 BMG (this one is simply scaled up 30-06 to accurate measures)
14.5x114 (.57 Cal Anti-Tank)

NOTE: Some tip shapes might not be 100% accurate as some bullets have a slight flat tip, however this should not effect the actual measurements and size at all.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.10mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Raft: Yes (might not be needed, but for myself it always results in better prints.)

Infill: 0% (with 2 shells it seems to be sturdy enough)

Print Temp: 210c (PLA) (I tried 220c but the tip melted lot more)

Print speed: 30 - 50mm/s

Print time: 20 - 60min (per item)

Note: Top Layer fill should be set to as low as possible to prevent a blob forming onto the tip.

Wikipedia + Blender

Using info from Wikipedia i was able to do accurate measures in blender to get the bullets as close to real life scale as possible.

5.56x45 7.62x39 9x19 30-06 45 ACP 308 Blender

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Fyq1FCPhV8

Hi!

This time i made a printable version of 'BIT', first CGI character of 1982 movie TRON

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fGujzulsas

There is 4 figures/states with their stands.

  • NO: Red Second stellation of icosahedron
  • YES: Yellow octahedron
  • IDLE 1: Blue Compound of icosahedron and dodecahedron
  • IDLE 2: Blue Small TriAmbic icosahedron

About the files:
For an easier print i've included some extra files:
bit_yes_layflat.stl : The octahedron laying in a face. You may need some infill to avoid gaps in the roof
bit_no_half.stl: Print two of this and use superglue to create the full stellated icosahedron. (no supports needed

Each stand fits with their corresponding figure. I've used a small ball of 'Blu-tack' to stick the stand and the figure. A bit of superglue will also work.

Credits to:
I've used some Opensad resources for the bit states:
Polyhedra in OpenSCAD: http://kitwallace.co.uk/3d/solid-index.xq (Generate Openscad files for lots of polyhedra)

The 59 stallations of icosahedron (WRL format): http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/stellations-icosahedron-index.html

And one of the polyhedra found in https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:192584

See below for some printing tips

Hope you enjoy it!
Have fun!
Use blu-tack or some sort of sticky gum Fix! Print two of these and use glue for the stellated icosahedron (no supports needed)

When having a small lathe, chips quite often fly into the morse taper of the tailstock causing a bad fit of tools. Leaving something like a drill-chuck is no option, because it takes too much room. A small dead center is short, but it is a little bit on the dangerous side ;-)

To get rid of that problem, I made a small plug with a fraction of a MT2 taper. With my print, it sits firmly enough to not fall out, but is yet easy to remove.

Settings are not important on this one. Use whatever fits your need.

print_settings.Notes:: The printing process must be special to make the propellers resistant and flexible, in fact in addition to set the percentage of filling to 100% must increase the number of perimeter shells to the highest possible number (I used 10), this will create a very elastic fiber that will prevent the rupture of the propellers.

title: Replacement propellers for the Parrot Bebop

description.text:
These are replacement propellers for the Parrot Bebop Drone, but they can be used for the Parrot Bebop 2 (in the future I will adapt them perfectly for this model).

My propellers was printed in PLA and are resistant and flexible like the original ones, the only flaw is that you have to sand them to make them smoother and more aerodynamic.

VERY IMPORTANT

The printing process must be special to make the propellers resistant and flexible, in fact in addition to set the percentage of filling to 100% must increase the number of perimeter shells to the highest possible number (I used 10), this will create a very elastic fiber that will prevent the rupture of the propellers.

Obviously, the propellers have been extensively tested in many weather conditions and I have not found any signs of failure.

If you like the project, put a like and share.

Do not forget to comment describing your tests and illustrating your ideas and possible improvements.

author: Alessandro_Palma

title: ENDER 4 support/adapter (ball bearings) for spool Ø 54 mm

description.text:
Français (English below)

J'aimais pas trop mes bobines posées directement sur la tige filetée M8 de ma Creality Ender 4

Du coup j'ai conçu ces supports simples et auto-adaptatifs à la largeur des bobines...pourvu que leur Ø central fasse 54 mm.

Les roulements utilisés sont des roulements à contacts obliques usagés, destinés à la poubelle, ....mais encore très bien pour servir dans cette application.

Ceci est ma première contribution...de débutant: je compte sur votre indulgence ;o)

English:

On my Creality Ender 4 recently bought, I did not like my coils placed directly on the M8 threaded rod.

So I designed these simple and self-adapting supports to the width of the coils ... provided that their central Ø is 54 mm.

The bearings used are used oblique contact bearings, intended for the trash, but still "healthy enough" to serve in this application.

This is my first post, as an "absolute 3D prints beginner"...I hope you will be indulgent

title: Carrera Go to 1st First Track Adapter

description.text: This is a Track Adapter to allow two different types of Carrera Go Track to connect together. It allows for the wider track to connect to to the narrower track. The only edition you will need is some sticky back copper tape which is readily available on Ebay, alternatively you may be able to use tin foil but would need to find some method of sticking it down. I ended up using wider copper tape and making it go over the ends a bit more to make a good electrical connection. I would suggest printing this with supports as the connectors and openings need it. I did not put a roof over the smaller connector holes as it was too difficult to remove the support material. I have thoroughly tested this model and it works great. Please not you will need to print at least two adapters. I would suggest removing the controller box from the secondary track as I found that with it part of the track even without batteries in it caused both cars to be controlled by one controller, its very simple to remove the block from the track if needed, or just don't use that piece of track.

description.text:
With my new Skywalker 1800 2014 (fpvmodel) I wanted to mount the video transmitter inside of the fuselage to protect it from crashes , weather and heat when the plane is stationary.
I fitted a 40mm fan (31.5 mm mounting hole spacing) that can activly cool the vtx. It can take 12V and consumes around 60mA.
P.S. the clip on bottom that you see in the Solidworks assambly does not fit the actual part (I did not include the .stl file of the bottom clip) . Want me to print your 3D part ? Visit:
http://www.3dhubs.com/arnhem/hubs/spikee Want to donate ONE dollar for my work ? Goto:
http://goo.gl/hVsLs0
Printed on Ultimaker 2 on lowest quality settings.

Bref, j'ai donc fait ce petit boitier avec un inter bipolaire et un voyant LED et du coup je décide quand je veux mettre en marche le ventilo radial additionnel.

Si ça peut servir à quelqu'un d'autre....

First, I connected the fan directly to the 24Vdc power supply block ... but ..., not always great for the first layer .... (I just start in 3D print world..., so a lot of stuff to learn ... )

So I designed this little switch box with a bipolar switch and LED indicator and then I can decide when I want to turn on or off the additional radial fan.

If it can help someone else ....

description.text:
This is a 3d model of a 0.96', OLED screen with I2C communication. I needed the 3d model of the part to precisely design its enclosure, so I made it in openScad.

There is a lot of variation between the different manufacturer, so this model may not be the exact copy of what you bought, but the scad file should be fairly simple to adapt (the scad file is not well commented and very messy, but is only 60 lines long).

button for automatic leash for dog
standing print
layer 0.2
PLA

Every wanted to make your mBot draw perfect squares, triangles or any other polygon? This holder is designed to keep a drawing instrument exactly between the robots wheels. So nothing gets drawn when you are turning. Now you can write programs to draw shapes with your kids.

-- Mounts under your mBot using four screws into the metal frame. There should have been some extra screws when you got your mBot which work perfect.

-- The holder snuggly fits a 1cm drawing instrument after cutting it down to size. If you want you can cut a slit between the base and the smaller half of the holder. Then after drilling a hole in the tab you have an adjustable drawing instrument holder. I tried printing this but it took too much support structures and was easier to drill out.

description.text:
thanks to the original designer:

Spiral drill sharpener adapter for proxxon
by noel841106, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2743361

i just scaled the file to the correct size.

you will need:
1x M3 screw (~12mm)
1x M3 nut
