This is a prototype that uses jopereira's excellent Y motor mount you can find here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437197. for this build you'll need:
m5 hex cap screw, 30mm long with nut
m4 screws, 6mm long x4
m4 t-nut x4
m3 6mm pulley x1
m3 hex cap screw 15mm long x1
m2 screws x2

For the pulley, the screw is acting as an axle so no nut is required, it should just slot in. The m5 tensioner screw needs to be press fit into the pulley mount, as well as the nut in the tensioning gear. The linear rail holes are exactly 8.25mm and the rods might need a little extra force pressing them into them. Included are pics for reference. The zip tie is unnecessary, just from a problem with my motor damper.
main transfer for shredder blender

The helmet is sized to fit an adult male but check the PDF file for measurements. Units are in millimeters.

print_settings.Notes:: Use a 0.3mm nozzle if you can. Otherwise 0.4mm will probably work ok.

description.text:
I'm using a Raspberry Pi in my latest project and I've been looking for a suitable mount.

I don't want a case, because I want access to the GPIO pins, and I'm not 100% sure of what else I'll be adding yet. I'll be using the camera, and probably adding a few buttons and maybe some lights.

There's a lot of cases on Thingiverse, but none of them seem to be exactly what I'm looking for. So I'll make my own! Hopefully some of you with the same needs and constraints may find this useful too.

This mount system consists of the base, and add-on pieces for the camera and some stripboard for prototyping. I've included a picture of the mounting dimensions for those that want to make their own custom add-ons for servos or sensors etc.

Each of the add-ons has relief to access the SD card when mounted on the front.

I use a 0.3mm nozzle for smaller things like this, although 0.4mm will probably work ok. Print the parts in PLA or PETG (I used PETG) at 50% infill, and after cleaning up with a knife run through each hole with a drill. 3.5mm for the countersunk assembly mounting holes, 2.5mm for the pilot holes for the countersunk assembly screws. 2.1mm for the pilot holes to mount the Pi and the stripboard.

The countersunk assembly screws are 3.5mm x 8mm woodscrews. These are used to secure the base to a mounting board, but also to secure the add-on pieces. These are a bit overkill to secure the add-ons but they're cheap and readily availble from DIY stores.

Use M2.5 x 8mm machine screws to secure both the Pi and the stripboard. Put a washer under each one, and let them self-tap the holes.

For ease of use, I've chosen to print little plastic posts to mount the camera. This allows for quick adding and removal, although you might need to trim a bit with a knife depending on how accurate your printer is. If you want something a bit more solid, trim them off with a knife, spot the centre and drill out to 1.6mm, using some M2 x 8 machine screws.

The stripboard mount is sized for a standard 0.1" pitch, with the mounting dimensions being 1" square. That's a small enough size to be able to add to the side without making the whole thing huge, while still being a useful size for buttons and LEDs etc.

I've added a Pi logo to make it look a bit more 'professional' too :-)

Hope someone finds this useful - leave a note in the comments or send me a private message if there are any issues.

Happy building!

Printer:

title: 3D Printed Hydrogen Fuel Cell
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello again.
This time I have printed up a Hydrogen Fuel Cell.
Also knows as a HHO Generator, Brown Gas Generator and also On Demand Hydrogen Fuel Cell.
The Stainless Steal parts can be purchased at your local Home Depot or Lowes or ACE Hardware stores.
Total cost for all stainless steal parts only cost less then $40 bucks.
But the fuel economy will jump from 20% up to 50% depending on your solution in the canister.
This version only uses 3.25 amp at 14.2 volts but gives me a fuel increase from 15 MPG to 25 MPG in my 1985 Ford Econoline 5.8 liter V8 Engine.
The lid must be printed at .96 or .97 size inside the Repetier-Host Software. if you don't print lid smaller then the canister and lid will not fit correctly.
The only extra item needed is either Cork to seal the lid to the canister or thin film of silicone to seal the canister.

As of 1/22/2018 This printed cell works great.
Original MPG on my van is 12-18, now with this cell the fuel economy Jumped up to 18-20 MPG.

comments.text:
Yes but Most people do not understand that we are extracting both O2 and Hydrogen, They understand Hydrogen Fuel Cell.
But once you explain, then they understand that we are pulling O2 and Hydrogen.
I agree with you 100% but not everyone will. They understand Hydrogen Fuel from Water.
comments.author: tlmxcpmpp

comments.text:
Its not a hydrogen fuel cell, nor a hydrogen generator, its a browns gas generator.
The result of this process is hydrogen and oxygen. Not just hydrogen.

title: Zodiac Barracuda MX8 Gearbox XShaft and other parts

description.text: One day, your Zodiac Barracuda MX8 pool cleaner will become loopy. Mine started manifesting signs of insanity when it no longer followed the usual patterns, and the pseudorandom behaviour I had come to know over the few years, became more of a spiraling nonsense - like a tortoise chasing it's tail. Each track is driven by a box filled with a reduction gearbox, and a right-angled combination of a cam shaft and a knife-edge follower (what I'm calling the X-shaft) The X-Shaft determines which gear is engaged (forward or reverse). In my case, the knife edge got worn to the point where it no longer engaged the track for the reverse option, making it spiral. This part replaces the original. Be sure to read Print Settings for an explanation of how these things come together.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There are two X-Shaft configurations depending on the side you are replicating... Either A or B. If you are not sure, open the cleaner and remove the drive box to reveal an "A" or "B" bossed on the enclosure.

To make drive A, join the two parts:

  • Zodiac Barracuda MX8 - CAM Side A.STL
  • Zodiac Barracuda MX8 - Knife Edge.STL
    OR just use Zodiac MX8 - XShaft Side A STL.stl

concentrically and in a right angle to each other, like shown in the photo.

To make shaft B:
I have not made this one yet because mine still works. But If I get enough encouragement, I can do B too.

Other Suggestions:

Minimum infill area: 30mm2
Support: Everywhere. I used zig-zag with line spacing of 6mm.

comments.text: I think the reason why these gearboxes dont last would be that too long hose is attached and the gears cant carry the weight of the hose, this happened to my father in law.

I'd actually like to like to redesign it with less friction i.e. wheel and track.  That way it would last FOREVER.

title: Cute Penguin with Updated Drawer Organizer Secret Compartment

description.text:
I loved the cute penguin drawer designed by chendragon2099, but I didn't want the drawer going all the way through the penguin. So I did a whole bunch of tinkering in Autodesk Fusion 360, closing off the hole in the back, making small cutouts in the front for gripping the drawer, and adjusting the drawer accordingly. I think it turned out beautifully! (It was a perfect anniversary present for my fiancée, who loves penguins.)

I recommend printing this in two batches:
Print A: "Penguin - Belly.stl"
Print B: Everything else.

Make sure you print everything at the same scale. And watch out for the beak, it's pretty sharp!

Yes

10%

Notes:

These files are optimized for printing on a multimaterial printer such as the Prusa i3 Mk2 MMU. Print it with a wide enough purge tower so that the colors don't mix too much when it gets to the penguin's face.

Not sure why, but Slic3rPE added some little loops of support above the eyes, so in some of the pictures it looks like it has eyebrows. They peeled off easily.

title: SRexorder - Recorder / Whistle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to see if I could make a mouth piece that actually made a note. I put two lower recorder section on the end so that I can make deeper notes.

It sounds really crisp.

Not sure if it's really playing notes yet. I'll do some math and probably fix this in the future.

Suggestions welcome!

Eventually I'd like to make a bunch of different mouth pieces, mid-bodies and bells that all use the same interface.
For instance a slide whistle mid-body that uses this mouthpiece might be cool.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

55%

Notes:

The mouthpiece prints out in about 3 hours with 55% infill, supports touching build plate and brim turned on.

The mid body and bell were printed out with 55% infill and brim turned on. about 3-4 hours each part.

Note on whistling part

It's really important to get the wedge making the noise even with the bottom of the wind slot. So print orientation is important. If you print he mouthpiece vertically, with the large layer height the tolerance will be poor on the wedge and you'll get a windy note. I set it up to print the wedge side on and that made all the difference.

If your printing with PET-G watch out for strings and general gooeyness filling up the air input part and killing the sound.

In this mouthpiece the hole after the wedge is an oval that necks down into the circular cross section of the instrument.

If you want to remix this design but use my mouthpiece the interface dimensions are:
The mid-body piece that goes into the mouthpiece is:
radius = 0.295 in, height = 0.25 in
With a chamfer of D1 = 0.06 in, D2 = 0.125 in

The bell part that goes into the mid-body is
Radius = 0.288 in, height = 0.375 in
chamfer D1 = 0.125, D2 = 0.06

title: Swiveling Wall Spot Lamp cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Like my first led light "The Arc" this lamp uses the Ledberg Spotlight from IKEA and shares some design ideas, like the two-part arm, the head and the round base. Other than "The Arc" this lamp is intended to be screwed on the wall for example besides a bed. That is why I made the swivel mechanism. The arm can be tilted by 45° to both direction, making it possible to reach an point with the light beam.

My build was done from 6,5 mm beech plywood on my desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft. A series of very small nails cut to be flush with the turing base and corresponding magnets makes the arm lock in position.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like the build.

Please be aware that the stl-file is for 3d viewing only! It will not give usable results when printed.

title: OctoPi Rig (Raspberry Pi 3 & Logitech C170 Webcam)

description.text:
An OctoPi Rig I put together with a few files I liked here on Thingiverse. I needed a case for the Raspberry Pi 3, a mount for my Logitech C170 Webcam, and decided to use Go Pro parts to build an arm assembly to attach the mount to the Pi case. I created the design in a fashion that the case would sit in front of my 3D Printer, with the webcam mounted to an arm off of the case, so it was raised up to have a clear view of the printer's print bed. With the addition of OctoPi, an SD card software image solution of Octoprint made for the Raspberry PI, along with the 3d printing of this design build, my OctoPi Rig became whole! Im posting the design i put together here in case others out there would like to use this OctoPi Rig too !

This rig is designed to use the Raspberry Pi 3 and a Logitech C170 webcam. You will need these in order to build this OctoPi Rig, along with a MicroSD card of at least 4GB, and can freely download the software image you will need to use from the Octoprint website. I highly recommend watching the video tutorial on their site while following the installation instructions provided there as well.

OctoprintI remixed & gathered a few files I came across here on Thingiverse to create a case with arm and a mount attached to it for the Raspberry Pi 3 and my Logitech C170 webcam.

Link's to the original works are added under the "remixed with" section. Thank you to the original designers for making this.project build much easier for me :-).

Happy Printing & Enjoy :-)

Please comment your thoughts of the design. If you have any questions, comments, thoughts, changes, edits, or requests for additional parts to be made to have the Rig accommodate your specific printer in any way. Weather that be a different mounting solution for the camera, the raspberry pi, or both, please let me know by submitting a request in the comment section. More then happy to aid/assist/generate new models for specific needs!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2813736
^^ See this Thing listing as an example! I created a version of this OctoPi Rig for a Printrbot Simple Metal !

Printer:

Dream Maker Overlord Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 Microns

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The arm model & the mount model both require support while printing however these are the only parts of the Rig that will need support while printing. The case top and bottom print fine without support as there is literally no need for them.

Happy Printing!

Design Process for OctoPi Rig

Design of this OctoPi Rig was fairly simple and straight forward. I wanted to make this as easy as possible. Seeing how i just needed a case for the Pi 3, of which there are a plethora on Thingiverse, I found one suitable for my design here and used that.

Then i followed the same process in looking for a mount for the Logitech 170 Webcam and found on here. I did the same again in searching Go Pro parts to create an arm attachment and connector base to the case in order to hold the mount for the webcam to the case. To make the Rig a one piece design, rather then having a camera arm to attach somewhere else on the printer.

Taking the case to Tinkercad for quick design editing, all i wanted to do was fill certain holes in on the case and erase a logo that was on it as well to make the case as plain looking as possible, while still being completely functional. I did so by using a rectangle shape that I then carefully positioned in various places on the case. By editing the dimensions, I was able to fit the shape to the case so that it would eliminate the specific hole i lined it up with, using the combine feature in Tinkercad to make the new rectangle a part of the case! Doing so eliminated the hole, and so i repeated the process until I was happy with the look of my new top and bottom for the case design. Then all i needed to do was export the new case Top and then Bottom as a new STL! Done so easily in Tinkercad by selecting the part you need and selecting export in the menu and voila, new STL!

Next, I used a similar process to subtract the Go Pro base connector from the Low profile tripod, this time using a large square as a solid to cut the tripod away from the connector. after this, i placed the connector base to the top half of the case model in a place that it would fit completely onto the model, in this case, being just above the slot hole designed for the micro SD card adapter.

Now, I had the case for the Pi 3 modeled exactly as I wanted it for the Rig. All i had left to do from this point on was to consolidate the various STL files into one folder to organize the project, and to have them available in one place come printing and also for uploading the files here onto Thingiverse. I put my new Case Bottom and Top STL's, edited on Tinkercad, into the folder. I then added the webcam mount STL & the Go Pro Arm STL as well.

Last but not least, For convenience and neat display of the Rig design on Thingiverse, i decided to create an STL of the entire Rig assembled. i did so by loading all the STL files of the Rig into Meshmixer (this could also have been completed in Tinkercad).

In Meshmixer, I used the Transform command to position all the STL files together in a fashion so that the Rig looked as if it was fully assembled. This took a few minutes to complete and once finished, i selected all model parts and exported them as an STL file from Meshmixer, essentially producing an assembled Rig in an STL file format, And added this file to my folder to complete the file list for this OctoPi Rig.

I printed the files because of course, the ultimate reason for this project was to build an Octoprint OctoPi Rig for myself to use for remote wireless 3D printing with my 3D printer! I then took completed pictures once i had printed all the respective parts to fully assemble the OctoPi Rig!

The print were all a success and all went well together very nicely. The project was a great success as i now have an Octoprint setup to use with my 3D printer! I uploaded all the pictures & STL's I organized together here onto Thingiverse to share my experience for all of you here. As well as to share the design itself, thinking that there may be some of you here online that would also like to have a setup like the one i created for yourself to use with your 3D printer too!

I hope including this description of my design process for this project helps others to understand how I did this so that they can learn and succeed in creating their own projects in future as well! You don't have to be a modeling master to get started! I am sure many of you are well aware of the process i used, and surely too, know of more advanced ways to accomplish the same. I did this as easily and simply as I possibly could, to show others that designing and modeling for 3D printing can be an easier process to get into then one might think. Also to demonstrate and explain the process as well for people new to 3D printing so that they can fully understand methods and tools that they too can easily start with themselves and achieve success with 3D modeling and 3D design as well!

Please enjoy this experience, this project as well if of course it is something you too would like to build, and above all...

Happy Printing! :-)

title: 1/2" EMT Pipe Dry Box Filament Spool Holder Support Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I started printing nylon and have found the tedium of needing to oven-dry it too much to take. I've also had occasional sputtering from PETG that had gotten a bit moist, so decided to resolve.

These are support backets for supporting 1/2" EMT pipe which is commonly available in the USA for pennies per foot. They can be used for any purpose but were intended to be used for creating dry-box like in this video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OY5n9q-wS7k

Enjoy !

-=dave

Dry Box Assembly

You'll need:

  • 1-gal of non-cobalt indicating desiccant: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01I5Y9H6A/
  • 10-lbs of non-indicating desiccant: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M5AO1PQ/
  • 4x Sterilite 20qt storage box with seal (locally available at Target stores in the USA): https://www.target.com/p/sterilite-174-20-qt-air-tight-storage-tote-transparent-with-blue-latch/-/A-15066036
  • 10' stick of 1/2" EMT (locally available at any HW store): https://www.homedepot.com/p/1-2-in-EMT-Conduit-101543/100400405
  • 8 of the brackets

Roughen the box side and bracket slightly with some sandpaper, then affix with hot glue with top of bracket about 30-35mm from ledge inside the box. It's not critical but you want to allow enough space underneath for the desiccant but also not have the spool hit the box top. Adjust accordingly based on your spools.

Cut 4x sticks of the 1/2" EMT to 313mm. A tubing cutter makes it much easier than using a hacksaw but whatever works: https://www.homedepot.com/p/Husky-Quick-Release-1-1-8-in-Tube-Cutter-80-772-111/204258904

Use one of the containers to mix all the desiccant together. This saves cost buy reducing the amount of more expensive indicating desiccant and the chemical it uses (more important if you are using the "blue" cobalt indicating desiccant, which is ever so slightly toxic). You can of course use all indicating desiccant if you want: it's your cash :). If you want to double this recipe to 8x boxes, you can probably just add 10lbs more non-indicating because there is still plenty indicating desiccant to show if it gets "wet" and the amount here can probably be stretched to 6 containers or more.

Crack open a beer because you're done.

title: Feet for Wanhao Duplicator 6 (WD6) Monoprice Ultimate

description.text:
So I bought two of Monoprice's Ultimate 3D printers (which are the rebranded Wanhao Duplicator 6), and one of them had an issue with the Z-axis. It turns out it didn't turn smooth enough for the stock stepper motor not to skip steps, so I got a bigger stepper motor that extends out the bottom, thus I needed some ground clearance. Enter creating new feet for the WD6. Honestly, the printer really needs these anyway way as it could use the extra room for better breathing (especially if you have it on the floor like I do), and the stock feet suck and won't stay on.

For something as simple as a foot there are quite a few design features:

  • They are press fit.
  • There are two pressure numbs at the top of the channel to hold tight.
  • At the bottom of the channel it squares off to mechanically lock the edge surface into place.
  • The internal geometries all have rounded transitions in order to improve force distribution to prevent stress fractures.
  • They incorporate a corner design for few a reasons:
    1. It stabilizes the machine, as the corners represent the absolute furtherest possible mounting points in both the X and Y.
    2. It enables more surface area for better load bearing.
    3. The apposing angles of the two adjacent walls help to lock and stabilize foot against all force vectors. Which prevent shifting and movement, rotation, and help to keep the foot on the printer.
  • The part is oriented to print at an angle that will provide maximum strength (as we aren't applying force against layer interfaces).
  • The ends are rounded in order to try to protect surfaces it may sit on.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

description.text:
My wife saw a hanging wooden dodecahedal light fixture at a craft show, and I thought I could make something similar. I couldn't find a dodecahedon model that seemed applicable, so I designed my own.

You will need to print 12 of the pentagon sides, 30 of the pins, and one bulb holder. I completed this project with a 1 kg roll of filament - just barely.

The model and bulb holder is sized for an Ikea GOTHEM hanging light cord set. We tried one of the cool-looking clear LED bulbs with yellow LEDs, but didn't think it was bright enough. I suggest a simple bright frosted LED bulb.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

20%, 100%

Notes:

I used 20% infill on the Pentagons & Pins, but 100% on the Bulb Holder. Supports are only needed for the Bulb Holder.

Finishing and assembly

I printed this with SainSmart wood-infused PLA using standard PLA settings.

After printing I sanded with a 400 grit sandpaper, then stained with Minwax Cherry Gel Stain (Gel stain found on Amazon, not available at my local hardware stores). I found that the best way to apply the stain was to use a kitchen sponge that was cut up into strips.

I used Gorilla Superglue Gel to glue everything together, wrapping each side with painter's tape to hold it together while curing. For attaching the bulb holder to a pentagon, I just set something heavy on top while curing.

print_settings.Notes:: 5 top and bottom layers, 4 perimeters and 20% infill will ensure very sturdy base, supports are recommended for magnet cavity.

title: Helping Hands Magnetic Base With Wiring Option

description.text:
I wanted a new base for helping hands but none of the existing once had all features I wanted:
1) Some trays in the base for loose stuff, like this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2576668
2) Magnetic base to make it more stable and heavier, inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:644998
3) Integrated wiring option for all pipes to be able to add LED lit magnifying glass, exhaust fan, probes or whatever.
4) Solid faux cast iron look which will go well with my other soldering equipment (looks are so important ;-)
Here you have it.
……………………
This base expects 1/4-20 threaded cooling pipes, like these https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008O14864
If you want to use different cooling pipes, just regenerate STL files with different thread.
I picked up these alligator clips https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072FJQ7BG to complete my "hands".
Bottom is weighted by this locally sourced magnet https://www.homedepot.com/p/MASTER-MAGNETICS-25-lb-Round-Base-Pull-Magnets-96324/203613132
I suggest to use short #6 Plastite screw to hold the magnet, but any short self taping screw will do. Just make sure it is short enough to not go through the top!
I finished my base with some self sticking felt pads so it lowers the magnetic force a bit and it is not that noisy.
……………………
Wiring for this base is an option. If you do not need it, there is a model without wire management. Base with wire management has two auxiliary compartments for some additional electronics if needed. I will be using it for Arduino Pro Mini to drive my NeoPixel lit magnifying glass (see soon as my other project).
……………………
Base is designed in OpenSCAD for extrusion width 0.5 mm and layer height 0.2 mm. 5 top and bottom layers, 4 perimeters and 20% infill will ensure very sturdy base, supports are recommended for magnet cavity. Print with PETG if you want to use it for soldering so base does not melt that easily.
……………………
Source file is included. If you remix, please also share your source file.
……………………
Note: And again, OpenSCAD preview picture sucks! Model works fine in OpenSCAD. Sorry about that.

FlashForge

Yes

0.2 mm

20%

Notes:

5 top and bottom layers, 4 perimeters and 20% infill will ensure very sturdy base, supports are recommended for magnet cavity.

comments.text:
It is a nice 3rd hand platform.
The write-up mentions the threads to be 1/4" 20. The ones I have are 1/2" 20
Is the thread size correct?
comments.author: valveman

comments.text:
Thread size is 1/4-20 NPT not 1/4" 20 which is obviously much smaller. It is pipe thread and it is common on cooling pipes from Amazon.
Source code is provided, so If you have different threads on you cooling pipes, I suggest to:
1) Get 3d model of your thread.
2) Subtract this model from simple cube in OpenSCAD, print it out and test if it fits properly.
3) Scale XY (not Z) to make it fit better, you will probably have to scale it up a bit.
4) Replace my thread with your thread are regenerate the model in OpenSCAD

print_settings.Notes:: The button would benefit from printing at higher resolution (0.1mm or 0.06mm layer height) but I printed all other parts at 0.2mm.

description.text:
This is a modular and expandable accessory rack for the Dyson V6 (and other similar models). It can be mounted alongside the Dyson rack without using any of the existing sockets, or it can be used completely standalone. The component parts can be assembled to make all sorts of different racks. You can even add more sockets to it later if you find you need them!

The parts are designed to fasten together with M3 countersunk screws and nuts. The individual components are fairly small, so should be printable even on small beds.

There are several different wall brackets to choose from (a picture is included to aid in selection).

Other hardware needed:

  • M3x10 or M3x8 countersunk screws and nuts. Hex head screws will be easier to fit.
  • One spring for each button. I used 5.6 x 17.5mm compression springs, which came out of a "Rolson 150 Piece Spring Assortment" set. These were too long so I cut them in two halves, and used half for each button.

Notes:

  • These sockets won't accept the rigid extension tube, so that needs to be stored in the original Dyson rack (as shown in the photo).
  • Before fitting the button, clean up the edge of the hole and the button to make sure they are both smooth.
  • To fit the button, place the spring on the small peg in the body, then add the button on top of the spring. Put one of the pivot pins in place, then gently push the other side of the button until the second pin snaps into place (it helps to slightly bend the wall with a screwdriver as you do this). Mine was printed in PLA and I was able to fit all four buttons without any problems.
  • The joints have a single hole at the bottom, so they can be secured to the wall brackets with a single screw from below (to conceal it).

I fastened some 18x34 wooden batten to the wall with two screws, then attached the 3D printed brackets to that. This means you can have a fairly long run of sockets without peppering your wall with holes!

I've included the SketchUp file which shows some examples of how the parts assemble. Have fun!

I would love to see some other Makes of these :-)

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell thickness

Infill:

20%

Notes:

NOTE: part "body1" will need support, as will "button1". All other parts print without supports.
There's also an alternative flat version of the button "button_flat" which will print without support and needs less clean up.

The button would benefit from printing at higher resolution (0.1mm or 0.06mm layer height) but I printed all other parts at 0.2mm.

description.text:
This is an tripod mount for my Ultra-Wideband Vivaldi Antenna available from Tindie.

https://www.tindie.com/products/hagster/ultra-wideband-vivaldi-antenna-800mhz-to-6ghz/

This allows you to mount two antennas together on a standard camera tripod. The antenna can either be used independently to feed 2 receivers, split as transmit/receive, or even combined together with a slitter/combiner to create a more directional array.

The mount features 3 tripod mount threads in case on gets damaged. Additionally it is possible to mount the antenna's vertically on the tripod. This may be useful if you wish to listen to satellites etc.

The base plate features 4 off cable slots to keep you RF cable nicely out of way. The design supports up to 3mm coax and works nicely with RG174 cable.

You will need 8 off M2.5 mm screws(up to 12mm long) to attach the antenna to this mount.

title: X endstop mount for Ender - 4 for stock carriage plate

description.text:
This remixes the awesome contribution from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2505837 in such a way, that it can be attached to the ender-4 stock carriage plate.

In comparison to the original, two elongated holes have been made in order to allow sliding over stock stock endstop mount. Also a third hole for mounting the stock endstop on this remix has been made.

It was necessary to relocate the x axis endstop in order to attach proper part cooling fan left to the hotend.

Hint:
I use lower x carriage stiffener which is the triggering point for the endstop, but if you attach a stud on the downward facing side of the x-axis, you can use this as a moveable triggering point.

title: Token Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley organizer

description.text:
Thanks to:
DNME for his permission to use his Target Lock Holder and ID Token Holder
GMBridge, his Token Holder is the basis of this thing
gluchows , the front of this Ordnance Token is found at the bottom of the Extra-Munition Token slot

This design is meant to be used with the Stanley 25 Compartement Organizer but should also fit the Harbor Freight one.

It allows you to store "all" token existing up to the creation date of this thing:
16 Focus Tokens
16 Evade Tokens
16 Stress Tokens
16 Critical Hit Tokens
16 Ion Tokens
16 Energy Tokens (for Huge Ships)
16 Shield Tokens
16 Extra Munition Token
13 Pairs of Target Locks (which is A-Z)
8 Sets of ID Tokens
4 Reinforce Tokens
4 Weapon Disabled Tokens
4 Tractor Beam Tokens
2 Cloaked Tokens
4 Jam Tokens
4 Harpooned Condition Tokens
1 A Debt to Pay Condition Token
1 Mimicked/Shadowed Condition Token (Thweek)
1 "I'll show you the dark side" Token (Kylo Ren)
1 Suppressive Fire Token (Captain Rex)
1 Rattled Token (Crimson Leader)
1 Fanatic Devotion Token (General Hux)
1 Damage Deck

EDIT (13.02.2018): The V3 Version is supposed to hold all tokens untill Wave XIV, so it adds/changes:
1 Optimized Prototype Token (Director Krennic)
1 Scrambled Token (Targeting Scrambler)
3 instead of 4 Jam Tokens
3 instead of 4 Tractor Beam Tokens

I've also designed a bunch of bins for ships to be used with this organizer.

title: Customizable tenting for Let's Split / ergonomic keyboards

description.text:
A customizable OpenSCAD script for generating tented mounts, originally for the Let's Split keyboard.

I designed this tenting for this case: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748621 but it should work for almost any Let's Split case, and really any split keyboard that fits nicely in a square shape (so ergodox is probably a no). The angle calculations are done for you, so all you have to do is input your desired inclination and the width / height of your case and voila.

Please note, I had to turn off minkowski rounding for the script in order to get customizer to not time out. If you want rounding, download the script and set mink_r to 1.

description.text:
This is a right hand side Monoprice Select Mini GoPro Mount with ball link for holding an LED light strip.

2 x M3 machine screw 8-12mm
2 x M3 nut
2 x M3 flat washer (optional, but recommended)
1 x M5 nut
1 x Extension arm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454206

This is the LED light holder I am using with this part, but I didn't like how the shadows on the part would change as the build plate moved under it during my timelapse, so this mount allows the light to move with the camera.

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

title: AM8 X Carriage & 40mm Rear Fan Duct

description.text:
I wanted to share an X carriage design for the Anet A8 and other similar printers. The goals are for it to be light weight, have a 40mm part cooling fan, and an accessible hotend.

The part cooling fan I am planning to use for this is the Noctua 40mm however others will fit. Instead of using screws to mount the fan silicone press-in anti-vibration mounts will be used.
https://www.amazon.com/Noctua-NA-SAV4-silicone-anti-vibration-mounts/dp/B071W6KYCG

Please post images if you make them and let me know if something isn't right so I can fix it. Enjoy!

UPDATE: I made a test print of the parts and found that the fan sits 2.5mm below the nozzle. I have temporarily removed the file. I will make some changes and re-upload the file.

UPDATE: 9 Jan 2018
Many changes were done to this thing so all the original files have removed and replaced with the new versions.

ADDITIONAL UPDATE: Made changes to the BLTouch mount, raising it up. NOTE: in the images the BLTouch is shown in it's "sensing" position which is below the nozzle....

ANOTHER UPDATE: The LM8UU bearing were 46mm C-T-C I have also added one the measures 45mm C-T-C. The files are marked accordingly. Please measure yours to determine which fits better...

UPDATE: 11 January 2018
Made some minor changes to the BLTouch mount making it stronger.

UPDATE: 14 January 2018
With some help from Brad on the Anet A8 3D Printer / Unboxing Facebook page, (Thanks!) it turns out that fan shroud will hit the acrylic frame returning to the X endstop switch. So it looks like this might be an AM8 only for the time being. I will be converting one of my Anet A8's over the next couple days to the AM8 and testing this carriage. Upon initial inspection it looks like it should work fine... More to follow...

UPDATE: 18 January 2018
The assembly has been installed on my latest AM8 frame and it works great. This is 67g lighter than the previous assembly I was using.

Since this design is so small it required that the X axis switch be relocated so that it would come into contact with the carriage. The file is now in the list....

UPDATE: 20 January 2018
Today I replaced the fan shroud with a new version. After some testing I found that the original wasn't performing well.The new version is performing much better.

A small modification was added to the original BLTouch mount. An access hole was created in the top. Also a second version of the BLTouch mount was also created. This one turns it 90 degrees to the front.

UPDATE: 24 January 2018
Today I added a new carriage with 2.8mm holes. This will allow you to directly screw 3mm screws into the plastic without the need for the brass inserts. This carriage is for the rod spacing of 45mm...

If you decide to print these files please post images and leave a small comment on how it worked for you. If tolerances are to tight or something please let me know so I can fix it. :-)

NOTE: If you appreciate the work I have done please buy me a coffee by clicking on the tip icon. :-)

Printer:

Anet A8 converted to AM8

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Fan Shroud - exterior supports only

Carriage - supports optional, if you use support removing it from around the belt tensioners might be an issue. If printing without support you will need to file the E3D mount hole a little to get it to fit.

BOM

M3 x 10 cap screws Hotend clamp and fan) - 6ea
M3 x 4 cap screws (fan shroud & BLTouch mount) - 4ea
M3 nuts or M3 nyloc nuts - 2ea
M3 x 5 threaded inserts - 6ea

E3D-V6 Hotend - 1ea
E3D-V6 Hotend sock (to protect fan shroud) - 1ea
40mm DC fan - 1ea
LM8UU Bearings - 4ea OR LM8LUU Bearings -2ea

Optional:
BLTouch - 1ea

Assembly

Since there are many sizes of threaded inserts available on the market the holes were made intentionally small at 4mm. It is very easy to use a drill bit with a handle attached to ream out the holes a bit. However you do want the holes to be smaller than the insert. To insert them, slide them onto the tip of a hot soldering iron (use pliers so you don't burn your fingers) and press them into place. If you are able to set the temperature I found 400 degrees Fahrenheit to work well.

Mounting the fan is straight forward. The holes are tight enough for a screw to self thread in. You can also use anti-vibration mounts as well which are a push fit. In the case you may need to rear out the holes a bit.

The LM8UU bearings are tight squeeze but they will go in with a little wiggling. :-)
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/auay6qXoCJU" ></iframe>

title: VERSION 2 - K40 Chinese Laser Head and Plate with Laserholder, Air-Assist, Beam Alignment Tool and removable Lensholder (for lenses with 12mm or 19mm diameter and focus of 50,8mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Sometimes it came to problems with th first Version of the laser head, where the focused laser-beam hit the lower part of the air assist. So I came up with a new concept, where the airflow is now guided through a small pipe next to the lens holder head. The pipe directs the airflow directly to the focal point of the laser-lens. This way it is now no longer possible that the focused beam hits the laserhead.

Furthermore I changed the Laserpointer-setup to work with line lasers.

To screw the lower part to the upper part I used M3 screws. I had to file down the lens holder a bit to get a good fit. The print is eiher for lenses with 12mm or 19mm diameter and focus of 50,8mm

comments.text: I hate the original K40 laser head, the way it screws in makes it so easy to become twisted and get unfocused. I have an 18mm lens so I modified the 19mm model to fit. I am printing the pieces on my Lulzbot Taz six and we will see if it's much better than the original (not hard to do)

description.text:
Ever find yourself needing a phone stand in the restaurant, in the office or at your favorite coffee shop? I have and many times I'd prop my phone up against my drink to watch something, or to keep the kids entertained while waiting for food or the check.
This fits inside your wallet and cost next to nothing in time and filament to print. This will eventually break at the folds due to the nature of the material used. But print a few extras for yourself, your friends, and co-workers.

Important
Be sure to latch the tap into the notch all the way

Use the first notch for horizontal viewing
Use the second notch for vertical viewing

I've tested this stand with the following phones without the phone falling over.
iPhone 6s with Otterbox Defender case (approx~ 15mm thick)

author: smysnk

print_settings.Notes:: Print flat face down (see last photo)

description.text:
This design stores the laundry detergent cup for Tide and Gain brand liquid laundry detergent containers and drains excess leftover soap back into the container.

  • Single print design (Print in Place)
  • Fits North American Tide and Gain 4.43L (1.17 US gal/150 fl oz)containers (Proctor and Gamble brands)

Stop wasting laundry detergent by rinsing out the cup or making a mess in your sink.

It is designed for Tide and Gain (Proctor and Gamble) which has a drain opening size of approximately 28mm and the outer thread diameter is 35mm and has a 3mm thread pitch. If you have a different brand, it may work if the dimensions are close to this. The Sunlight brand containers have smaller drain openings so will not fit with this design.

UPDATE Jan 25, 2018
I've uploaded a .step file as per request.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10-40%

Notes:

Supports are required to allow the cap to be printed in place. Use fragile supports so they are easy to remove from the small gap between the cap and the part.

Be sure to set your support material minimum overhang settings to 80% or so or else the drainage channel will be filled with support material and the print won't work!

Print flat face down (see last photo)

Fusion 360

I designed this with Fusion 360. I took photos of the threads and used the attach canvas feature to create the threaded cap. The rest was straight forward. I had some fun coming up with a drainage channel design that would print without creating excessive overhangs.

The goal was a single print with no post processing other than removing support material for the cap and the very top of the tray.

comments.text: This is an amazing idea and exemplary design.  Thank you for doing it.
comments.author: monkeylabs

comments.text: Thanks, I'm glad you like it. If you are using Cura there is a work around, I didn't think it was worth making custom supports because you can adjust the overhang support angle to 80 degrees and the supports to support everywhere. This will support overhangs only above 80 degrees, which will keep supports on the cap and the overhang at the very top of the print but not inside the drainage channel. Hopefully this works for you and everyone else too!
comments.author: monkeylabs

comments.text: thanks for the reply and hint.  will changing that from the stock 50deg to 80deg for "everywhere" supports also remove them from INSIDE the throat of your model?  trying to avoid having supports inside the structure for proper drainage
comments.author: davwilso

comments.text: Yep that’s the idea, you can play with the angle and check in the slicer to verify the supports are only where you want them. I set it to 80 degrees and it eliminated the supports inside the throat but kept them for the cap and the top of the tray where you need them.

comments.author: kroymander

comments.text: Thanks for the comment, I’m glad you asked that question actually. Ironically, I used to do the same thing. I’d pour the detergent into the washer and put it back on the shelf with a little left in the cup. Over time you may notice that it begins to build up in the cup, which I’m guessing is the water evaporating and leaving behind a thick gel. Eventually you’ll have to rinse it out because it doesn’t just pour out in the next wash if it’s been sitting for a week. Or maybe you don’t have that problem. If you don’t, maybe ask your husband/wife/mom if they rinse the cup out when they do laundry.

title: Asus MB169b+ portable USB LCD stand

description.text:
Stand which will hold your portable USB properly on portrait and landscape modes. The case which can be turned into a stand is too finicky to have it for some proper setup. The legs are reaching good bit to back and bit in forward so it should make stable stand no matter what. The stand itself is 3cm wide and is meant to be printed multiple times, even when in landscape mode you might get away just with 1, I still prefer to use 3 of them to make it really riggit, for portrait mode even 3-4 of them.

Can be printed on lowest settings 0.3mm height without any support, 3 perimeters, 3 top and 3 bottom layers, and even 15% infill could be enough, I think from the top/bottom and perimeters is the most of the strength.

The fit is tight, so you might want to observe you bezel (I found out that my model doesn't have perfectly flat bezel and actualy there are gemotry changes maybe in 0.5mm scale, but there are changes, so on some places it might be too tight, still it works on all places I could imagine).

There is parametric source file where you should be able to tweak and change the dimensions easily.
